HEADLINE: Sanctions Lifted, Libya Withholds Final Lockerbie Payment

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7 

 BODY:
Libya is holding off on making hundreds of millions of dollars in payments to the families of Americans killed in the bombing of a Pan Am jumbo jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988. The payment appears to have fallen victim, at least for now, to a Libyan desire for a prominent public acknowledgment of its rehabilitation, according to people expert in the dispute.
 The payments were to have been made when the United States removed Libya from the list of states that sponsor terrorism, which Washington did on June 30. 
In August 2003, Libya promised payments of $10 million for each American on the Lockerbie plane, which carried 259 people, mostly Americans, to be paid in installments, and put $2.7 billion in escrow in a Swiss bank. It released $4 million for each victim in September 2003, as agreed, when the United Nations ended its sanctions, and $4 million in 2004, when the United States lifted some economic sanctions. The last $2 million was supposed to be paid when the United States took Libya off the list of nations supporting terrorism.
 But the settlement negotiated between Libya and lawyers representing the victims expired in July 2004. The American lawyers arranged a series of extensions, the last of which expired in February, according to lawyers for the American victims.
 On May 15, the State Department gave a 45-day notice required by law that it intended to normalize relations with Libya. Near the end of the 45 days, on June 25, a Libyan lawyer representing his government said in a press release that ''the settlement agreement expired, and the Escrow Account agreement also came to an end.''
 ''Consequently,'' his statement continued, ''the remaining amount for which the corresponding condition had not been fulfilled was returned to its source.''
 The State Department lifted the sanctions five days later, without announcement, though the Libyans were seeking a public embrace. 
 According to a government official involved in foreign policy, who would not speak for attribution because of the sensitivity of the topic, Libya was seeking an invitation to the White House for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, or at least a visit to Tripoli by an important American official.
 State Department officials have said that Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has been discussing making such a visit, but that she had decided not to do so, yet.
 Pan Am 103 was a Boeing 747 en route to New York from London. It exploded over the Scottish village of Lockerbie. All those aboard were killed, as were 11 people on the ground. Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, a Libyan intelligence agent, was sentenced by a Scottish court in 2001 for 270 murders; he must serve at least 27 years before he is eligible for parole, the court ruled.
 The Libyan press release, which said Libya was no longer obligated to make any payments, was attributed to Judge Azzam Eddeeb of the ''Libyan Legal Team.'' It did not rule out eventual payment, saying ''we shall deal with these cases most transparently and in complete good faith.''
 The statement dealt with three Libyan attacks: the Lockerbie plane, the bombing of La Belle discotheque in what was then West Berlin in 1986, and the bombing of a French airliner in 1989. The disco was frequented by American servicemen and the bomb killed three Americans and seriously wounded about 90, according to the American lawyers. The bombing of a jet belonging to U.T.A., a French airline, over Niger , killed all 171 people aboard. 
 But Stuart H. Newberger, who represents seven American victims in that crash and the owner of the plane itself, a DC-10, said there had been no recent negotiations, and a court judgment against Libya was approaching. A lawyer for the disco victims, Steven Perles, said there had been no settlement. 
 James P. Kreindler, a lawyer who specializes in aviation disasters, said that only the Lockerbie escrow agreement had lapsed, not the underlying compensation agreement. And action by the United States government was delayed, he said, because the Libyans had plotted in 2004 to kill Abdullah, then the crown prince of Saudi Arabia. 
 ''Libya can't get a windfall for that,'' he said, contending that the Libyans would benefit from their plot against the Saudi prince if that kept them on the terrorism list long enough to save them from making the last payment to the Lockerbie victims.
 He added: ''They are looking for a lot of public recognition for their new role in the world. I'm sure our settlement is a piece of that puzzle.''
 In a briefing on May 15, Sean McCormack, the State Department spokesman, said the settlement was between the government of Libya and the American plaintiffs. ''We weren't party to that agreement,'' he said.
 State Department officials acknowledge, however, that compensation by Libya to the American victims of its terrorism was a prerequisite to the normalization of relations that is now under way, 
 The House of Representatives, at the urging of the American families, passed a bill before the July 4 recess that included a provision preventing the opening of an American embassy in Libya or a Libyan embassy here until the payment is made. The provision was introduced by John E. Sweeney, a Republican from upstate New York, who cited a couple in his district whose daughter, son-in-law and two granddaughters died on the plane, among others.
 The Senate has not acted on the legislation. 
 The Libyan mission to the United Nations did not respond to a telephone message seeking comment.

HEADLINE: China Fights Sanctions To Punish North Korea

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE and NORIMITSU ONISHI; Warren Hoge reported from the United Nations for this article and Norimitsu Onishi from Seoul, South Korea.

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 7 

 BODY:
Japan introduced a Security Council resolution on Friday calling for sanctions against North Korea for its missile test-firings, but China opposed the move, saying such action could disrupt diplomatic efforts under way in the region.
 As the diplomacy unfolded, Christopher R. Hill, the top American negotiator with North Korea, was in Seoul, South Korea, trying to rally support in that region for a tough, unified response to the North's testing of seven missiles on Wednesday.
Mr. Hill, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, met with Chinese officials, including Li Zhaoxing, the foreign minister, in Beijing before arriving in Seoul on Friday evening. 
 China agreed that resuming the six-nation talks over North Korea's nuclear program was a priority, Mr. Hill said. But it did not appear that he had made progress in persuading the Chinese to endorse sanctions. 
 At the United Nations, Kenzo Oshima, the Japanese ambassador, said he hoped for a vote as early as Saturday, but Jean-Marc de la Sabliere, the ambassador of France, which is president of the Council, said that a date would be announced Monday.
 Britain, France and the United States are sponsors of the measure.
 The decision to put the resolution to a vote followed meetings Thursday and Friday involving Japan and the five permanent members of the Council -- Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States -- that failed to establish common ground. China and Russia said they preferred the less forceful measure of a presidential statement, which is nonbinding and does not threaten punishment.
 Entering the American mission for the gathering Friday morning, Wang Guangya, the Chinese ambassador, said, ''A resolution might have negative reactions in the region.'' He added, ''The Security Council's message should be responsible, taking into account the possible consequences.''
 Diplomats said Mr. Wang made the point forcefully in the closed consultations, and he told reporters afterward, ''If this resolution is put to vote, there will be no unity in the Security Council.''
 Asked whether he might exercise China's veto, he said, ''All possibilities are open.''
 The resolution condemns the missile firings, orders Pyongyang to cease missile development and recommit to a moratorium on launchings and urges member states to prevent missiles and missile-related items from reaching North Korea. It also calls on countries to keep the North from selling or transferring any such materiel. 
 Drawn up under Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter, the resolution ''strongly urges'' North Korea to rejoin the six-party talks on its nuclear program.
 Vitaly I. Churkin, the Russian ambassador, which also favors a presidential statement instead of a resolution, remained silent during the consultations, according to diplomats. Emerging from the Council chamber, he brushed aside reporters' requests for comment.
 John R. Bolton, the United States ambassador, signaled a willingness to continue negotiating the text of the resolution. ''We're certainly prepared for further conversations as other diplomatic efforts in the region continue,'' he said.
 But he added: ''We want a resolution. It should be Chapter VII, and I think that's clear. The level of provocation engaged in by these North Korean missile launches warrants that, and we're going to proceed.''
 Mr. Hill is expected to meet South Korean officials over the weekend before flying to Tokyo and Moscow, but he gave an indication on Friday of the message he is expected to convey. ''We shouldn't have business as usual with a country that's been firing off missiles like this in this rather reckless way,'' he said.
 South Korea said Friday that it would go ahead with four-day, high-level ministerial talks with North Korea next week in Pusan, South Korea. But South Korea said that it would delay shipments of food and fertilizer to the North and that it had turned down an offer, made by North Korea several days before the launchings, to hold military talks. 
 North Korea fired the missiles, including the new long-range Taepodong 2, despite warnings not to by its friends in China and South Korea.

HEADLINE: The Environmental Procrastination Agency

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
Now that the Supreme Court has gotten itself into the global warming debate, the justices face a choice: Should they rule in favor of environmental groups, or in favor of the environment?
 The court agreed last week to hear a case brought by the Natural Resources Defense Council and other groups seeking to empower the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate emissions of carbon dioxide from cars. To David Schoenbrod, the case sounds unfortunately familiar.
In 1972, as a lawyer for the council, he started the litigation that forced the E.P.A. to take lead out of gasoline. Technically, it was a victory for environmentalists, but it took so long that Schoenbrod decided his comrades in the movement had made a big mistake -- the same mistake they're now making with carbon dioxide. They keep expecting the E.P.A. do an impossible job. 
 They still believe in the Spaceship Earth management style, as Schoenbrod describes it in his book, ''Saving Our Environment from Washington.'' They still imagine the planet as a ship that must be guided by a wise captain, aloof from politicians and voters, who issues orders from the bridge with the help of his trusty crew of technocrats and lawyers. 
 ''The idea in creating the E.P.A. was that only an expert agency insulated from politics can protect the public and the environment,'' says Schoenbrod, now a professor at New York Law School. ''But what it really does is insulate Congress from responsibility for making tough choices. The legislators can take credit for passing laws protecting the environment, and the agency takes the blame for the inevitable delays and compromises and costs.''
 When the E.P.A. was created in 1970, Schoenbrod naively expected it to quickly deal with the known dangers of lead in gasoline. But the agency stalled through both Republican and Democratic administrations because neither party wanted to be blamed for hurting oil refiners or raising gasoline prices. The E.P.A. didn't get the job done until 1985, when it was politically expedient because the economics had changed and oil refiners favored getting rid of leaded gasoline. 
 The E.P.A. would have a far tougher time regulating carbon dioxide because the issue is so much more complicated than lead pollution. There isn't an obvious technical fix for bureaucrats to mandate. The potential sacrifices are enormous and would inspire at least a decade of wrangling and litigation. Any serious solution requires international cooperation. The only way to come up with a workable plan is for politicians to debate and negotiate.
 Schoenbrod's modest proposal for saving the environment is to strip the E.P.A. of its rule-making powers and convert it into an advisory and enforcement agency. It would do technical studies and make recommendations, leaving the lawmaking up to legislators -- usually legislators outside Washington. Except for some large-scale problems, like acid rain or global warming, Schoenbrod thinks that most environmental questions should be settled at the state and local level. 
 His ideas, of course, are not popular in Washington. Corporate lobbyists find it easier to work behind the scenes at the E.P.A. than to conduct public fights on Capitol Hill or in state capitals. Environmental groups also prefer federalizing issues, partly because they've got centralized operations themselves, and partly because they espouse the ''race to the bottom'' theory: if Washington were to delegate power, the states would be so desperate to protect jobs and attract industry that they'd compete to have the weakest environmental rules. 
 But in practice, as Schoenbrod demonstrates, Washington stops local officials from racing to the top. After the dangers of lead were recognized in the 1960's, New York City began taking steps to encourage unleaded fuel, but it and other localities were pre-empted from passing stricter rules once that became the job of the E.P.A. 
 While Congress and the E.P.A. have been dithering about global warming, California is requiring carmakers to reduce their emissions of carbon dioxide. New Hampshire has ordered power plants to restrict carbon dioxide and other pollutants. More than a dozen states, including Texas, require utilities to use renewable sources of energy.
 While the Kyoto accord is dead in Washington, a coalition of Northeastern states is setting its own Kyoto-style limits on greenhouse emissions and establishing a market for trading carbon-dioxide credits. 
 If the states keep setting examples, Congress may finally feel enough pressure to do something itself on global warming. But if the Supreme Court decides to entrust that job to the E.P.A., don't expect any commands from the Spaceship's bridge any time soon.

HEADLINE: The Credit Game Is Getting a Second Scorekeeper 

BYLINE: By DAMON DARLIN. 
Email: yourmoney@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Few things in life are as important as understanding your credit score, the number that lenders use to determine the interest rate you pay.
 To many consumers it has always been mysterious, and it's about to become even more so.
That is because the credit reporting agencies -- Experian, TransUnion and Equifax -- have come up with their own version of a credit score, called Vantage-Score. They are not doing this because they want to help consumers or expand the sale of their $6 credit score reports. 
 They are doing it because they want lenders to start using their scoring system. That is where the real money is; the Fair Isaac Corporation, which reported $798.7 million in revenue last year, dominates the market with its classic FICO credit score.
 The computer programs of Fair Isaac analyze the data on a credit report and predict whether a borrower would make a late payment of 90 days or more. It associated those odds to a score of 300 for deadbeats and 850 for sterling borrowers. Half of America's consumers are above 720 and half are below it. 
 If a borrower was rated at 720, a lender knew the odds of that borrower's being a credit risk were the same no matter what credit bureau the data came from. The FICO score broadened the availability of credit to more consumers, and -- there is a dark side to everything -- enabled the marketing of those preapproved credit card offerings that fill mailboxes. 
 A few years ago, when Congress began making noises about regulating scoring, Fair Isaac started to educate consumers about their scores. Its www.myfico.com Web site is one of the best sources for information about your credit score and how to improve it. It is also where you can go to buy a credit score report.
 If you want a credit report, you are entitled to a free one from each agency each year. Go to www.annualcreditreport.com to get those. Don't go anywhere else.
 The credit agencies have tried to grab Fair Isaac's business before with their own proprietary credit scores. The products were not widely adopted by lenders because each agency used a different scoring system with different scoring ranges, which made it difficult for lenders to manage risk. It left consumers confused because each agency gave out a different number. It was not unusual to see variance of a hundred points or more, a frightening prospect because a hundred points can mean the difference between an 8.13 percent mortgage and a 6.76 percent one. 
 The agencies banded together in March 2005 and buried their rivalries long enough to come up with VantageScore. They said the new system improves risk prediction by weighing more factors. They also said it more accurately measured consumers with ''thin files,'' their term for someone with a short credit history. 
 The VantageScore also takes into consideration the changing styles of borrowing, as in, for instance, the way Americans use their home as a bank by taking out home equity loans. ''It reflects more current behavior,'' said Stan Oliai, vice president for consulting and decision analytics at Experian.
 VantageScore has some virtues for consumers. The consortium assigns a letter grade to groups of scores, making it easier to understand. If you have A credit, you know you are at the top of the class. If you receive a C, you know, because you have undoubtedly heard it from teachers, that you have room for improvement. 
 Like Fair Isaac, the credit agencies also assign a three-digit number score. Their scores are from 501 to 990. 
 They knew it would be confusing, but they said they had to use three digits because if lenders are going to adopt their system, the lenders would want to keep the same software that has three spaces for a credit score. Fair Isaac had cleverly staked out the dead center with its range.
 The credit agencies created Vantage-Score to lure lenders; what consumers think is secondary. ''I wouldn't say consumers don't matter,'' Mr. Oliai said, ''but getting lender adoption is the sharp end of the spear.''
 When you need to borrow money to buy a car or a house, a lender may explain that you had a credit score of 750. Good? If the lender is using FICO, you'll get the best interest rate. If the lender is using VantageScore, however, you are considered strictly average.
 For the consumer, you have gone from having a bit more clarity about why lenders are quoting a particular interest rate to murkiness. Tom Quinn, vice president for scoring for Fair Isaac, has a vested interest in protecting the FICO score from competition, but he does have a point: ''If I want to be empowered, I want to know the tool that the lender is using.''
 The solution is to ask every lender what system it is using. Most lenders will not be using VantageScore for at least six months, probably as long as 18 months. Each lender needs to test the scoring system to see how effective it is at measuring credit risk and how it compares with a next-generation FICO score that Fair Isaac has developed to compete against it. 
 Until VantageScore catches on -- and it might not -- there is no need to buy a VantageScore report. (Experian is the first to offer the reports at www.vantagescore.experian.com.) There is no reason to buy any credit score unless you are unsure of how good your credit is and you will be borrowing in the next six months to a year. It will take at least that long to improve the score.
 Fair Isaac points out another potential problem. The two systems assign different weights to various factors of consumer credit use to come up with a score. It is possible, but a consumer will never know for sure, that some behavior might improve one score, but hurt another. 
 Mr. Quinn of Fair Isaac bought his VantageScore to compare it. His company placed him in the 76th percentile of creditworthy Americans, meaning that 24 percent of Americans have better credit. His VantageScore made him look better. It said he was in the 89th percentile. He does not know why. 
 The report that came with his competitor's score also said that he would have done even better if he had more available credit. That advice befuddled Mr. Quinn because opening another credit card account or raising his credit limit on existing cards could boomerang and make his FICO score worse. 
 The discrepancies are unlikely to happen often because Fair Isaac and the credit agencies agree on the main things that make a good borrower. They consider paying your bills on time as next to godliness. They all say that the longer your credit history, the better your credit. Get credit, but don't use that much of it.
 Are the two scoring systems equivalent? Who knows? Fair Isaac says it does not know. The same is true of Experian. ''Like everything in the credit industry, it is still a big black box,'' said Matt Fellowes, a senior research associate at the Brookings Institution who has studied credit scoring. 
 Consumers will never know because they will not have access to the algorithms and the estimated 200 million credit files. No one will know until lenders crunch the data.
 There is nothing that anyone can do about it. No one likes monopolies; competition is praised because it offers choice and usually lowers prices. That's what will happen for the real consumers of credit scoring -- the lenders.
 For the rest of us, it is going to be confusing.

 BODY:

INSURER DISCUSSES BID FOR AMERUS -- Aviva, the largest insurance company in Britain, said it was in talks to buy the AmerUs Group, an insurance company based in Iowa, in a deal that would increase its presence in the American market.
 AmerUs, of Des Moines, confirmed the talks but said there was no assurance a transaction would result. The company provides life insurance and annuity products and has a market capitalization of $2.4 billion.
 AmerUs Group's major operating subsidiaries include the AmerUs Life Insurance Company, the American Investors Life Insurance Company, the Indianapolis Life Insurance Company and the Bankers Life Insurance Company of New York.
 Analysts say a successful bid would have to be at a premium. Stock in Amerus rose $4.39, to $66.90 a share yesterday. If a deal is reached, Aviva said it expected to pay for it with combination of Aviva's internal resources, external debt and a sale of Aviva shares. (AP)

LABRANCHE SHARES FALL 24% -- Stock in LaBranche & Company, the New York Stock Exchange market maker, fell 24 percent after the company forecast an unexpected second-quarter loss. Stock in LaBranche fell $3.02, to $9.42 a share. 
 LaBranche said it expected to report a second-quarter net loss of about $23 million, in contrast to a profit of $8.7 million a year earlier. Revenue for stock trades using LaBranche's own capital fell to $20 million in the second quarter from $47 million a year earlier.
 The chief executive, Michael LaBranche, left, said the slide in global equity markets during May undermined trading opportunities in stocks, options and exchange traded funds. The New York Stock Exchange composite index, which tracks all the companies listed on the Big Board, had its biggest monthly decline in May since 2002. The second-quarter results included a $17 million loss because of a decline in the value of shares LaBranche owns in the NYSE Group. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

BID FOR FALCONBRIDGE EXTENDED -- Xstrata extended its hostile takeover bid of 16.1 billion Canadian dollars ($14.5 billion) for the Canadian nickel miner Falconbridge by two weeks, to July 21. The previous deadline for the offer, 52.50 Canadian dollars a share, was yesterday.
 Xstrata pushed back the bid deadline after the Canadian government extended its review of the deal. 
 ''I wouldn't be wholly surprised if they increased their offer at a later date,'' said Greg Smith, a London-based analyst at the investment adviser Fat Prophets. Xstrata is battling a rival offer for Falconbridge from the Phelps Dodge Corporation, which said on June 26 that it had agreed to acquire Falconbridge and Inco of Canada for about $35.4 billion. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

MERGER IN DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING -- Primedex Health Systems will buy a rival, Radiologix, for $82.5 million in cash and stock to become the largest operator of diagnostic imaging centers in the United States.
 Investors in Radiologix will receive $3.59 a share in cash and Primedex stock, 60 percent more than the closing price on Thursday, Primedex said. The combined company, to be called Radnet, will operate 132 centers and generate more than $400 million in annual revenue.
 Primedex, which is based in Los Angeles, valued the transaction at $208 million, including debt to be acquired. Radiologix has $45 million of cash and $170 million in debt, said Miles Highsmith, an analyst at Wachovia Securities. Shareholders of Radiologix, based in Dallas, will own 33 percent of Radnet, Primedex said. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

HORIZON HEALTH CUTS FORECAST -- The Horizon Health Corporation sharply cut its fiscal 2006 earnings view for the second time and lowered its 2007 outlook, setting off a 32 percent decline in its share price. Horizon, citing a decline in its contract management business, lowered its outlook after the close of market trading Thursday. Stock in the company, which is based in Lewisville, Tex., fell $6.46 yesterday, to $13.83 .
 Horizon also posted lackluster results for its fiscal third quarter, which missed Wall Street's expectations by 6 cents a share. The company said it expected fiscal 2006 earnings a share to be 78 cents to 80 cents. Horizon had previously projected 2006 earnings of 92 cents to 97 cents, which was cut from a February forecast of $1.08 to $1.12. (DOW JONES/AP)

JOB DECLINE IN CANADA -- Canada's economy unexpectedly lost jobs in June, the first decline this year, led by builders, retailers and wholesalers. Employers shed 4,600 workers last month, while a drop in the labor force kept the unemployment rate at 6.1 percent, the lowest since 1974, Statistics Canada said.
 The report suggests the Bank of Canada's seven rate increases since September are slowing an economy the bank says is at full capacity, and may allow policy makers to pause at their meeting on July 11. 
 Builders laid off 19,200 workers in June, while wholesalers and retailers laid off 16,700 employees. Factory employment, which has tumbled 8.5 percent since the end of 2002, fell by another 4,100 workers in June. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

AWARD WIDENED IN CABLE CASE -- The DirecTV Group, the biggest satellite television company in the United States, may owe at least $37 million more in damages and interest to the Finisar Corporation in a patent case.
 Finisar is owed $25 million in additional damages for DirecTV's infringement of a data-transmission patent, plus at least $12 million in interest, Finisar said. Finisar won the case after a nine-day trial last month. At issue in the case, which was filed in April 2005, was a patent for transmitting and broadcasting digital information to a wide base of recipients, Finisar said June 26.
 DirecTV was ordered to pay Finisar, a maker of optical-networking systems, $78.9 million on June 23 after losing the case in Beaumont, Tex. Finisar, citing a ruling in Beaumont, said the added payments were awarded because of the willful nature of the infringement. DirecTV said it would challenge the decision. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

PROFIT INCREASES FOR GAZPROM -- Gazprom, the Russian natural-gas producer, said that profit rose 49 percent last year, less than expected, as costs ballooned by almost a third after. Net income rose to 315.9 billion rubles ($11.8 billion), from 211.7 billion rubles a year earlier, the company said. Gazprom said expenses rose 30 percent whjle revenue rose 43 percent to 1.4 trillion rubles. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

HOME DEPOT'S MARKETING CHIEF LEAVING -- Home Depot said its marketing and merchandising chief, Tom Taylor, is stepping down after 11 months in the job. Mr. Taylor, 40, is leaving the company at year-end and will help find his successor, Home Depot said. He will become a consultant to the company and said he planned to spend time with his family. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

HEADLINE: Fighting Diseases With Checkbooks 

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
When Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive of the Oracle Corporation, pulled back recently from a plan to donate $115 million to Harvard, Richard L. Sprott was reminded again of the tenuous nature of his livelihood. 
 Mr. Sprott is the executive director of the Ellison Medical Foundation, a philanthropy that has received $175 million from Mr. Ellison mostly to aid research on the science of aging. Although the Harvard situation was unrelated to the foundation -- Mr. Ellison reportedly changed his mind about donating after the resignation in February of Lawrence H. Summers, the president of Harvard, amid a storm of controversy -- the events reinforced for Mr. Sprott his awareness that his organization also depended on a single billionaire.
''We exist only so long as Larry's happy,'' he said. 
 Wealthy individuals, through their philanthropies and the causes they support, like Michael R. Milken for prostate cancer and Michael J. Fox for Parkinson's disease, are a growing force behind medical research these days. 
 And with the largess comes concern about a potential overreliance on the generosity of the wealthy. 
 ''To rely on a few philanthropic organizations, however rich and well intentioned they are, does present significant risks,'' said Nicolas de Torrente, executive director in the United States for Doctors Without Borders, which provides health care in developing countries.
 The spotlight on the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which experts say is already setting much of the world's agenda when it comes to fighting diseases in developing nations, has brought such concerns to light. The foundation was helped greatly last week when Warren E. Buffett said that he was giving the foundation $31 billion, most of his fortune. The gift will double the foundation's assets. 
 The world is fortunate that Mr. and Mrs. Gates are focused on health problems of the developing world, Mr. de Torrente said. But, he added, ''What happens if they change their mind or de-emphasize something?''
 He said there needed to be an institutionalized multinational system to assure such research takes place. The World Health Organization, at its meeting in May, took some initial steps to start planning such an effort.
 Another concern is that governments will cut spending if they believe that philanthropies are taking care of a problem. A study done last year by the London School of Economics and the Wellcome Trust said that so-called public-private partnerships -- a recent phenomenon governments, charities and companies uniting to develop drugs for neglected diseases -- were being financed mainly by philanthropies. 
 ''We are in a current climate where the government is saying 'Let philanthropy do it,' '' said Sara Engelhardt, president of the Foundation Center, a research organization. 
 Others say that wealthy philanthropists can spend their money on their own pet causes, either to support their business or their ideological interests. 
 An example is the Dr. Robert C. Atkins Foundation, which was started by the late creator of the Atkins Diet to prove the benefits of eating low-carbohydrate foods. After he died in 2003, his wife, Veronica Atkins, who also said she wanted to vindicate her husband's reputation, became chairwoman. When Mrs. Atkins dies, the foundation's assets will grow to more than $500 million from about $40 million now, making it even more of a force in nutrition studies. 
 But the foundation, which has endowed chairs at several medical schools, says it is now supporting general research in diabetes and obesity. It has no relationship to Atkins Nutritionals, a company started by Dr. Atkins to sell low-carb foods and other products. 
 Abby Bloch, executive director for programs and research at the foundation, said it believed in the benefits of the Atkins diet, ''but we don't insist the investigators whom we support or sponsor believe this or prove this.''
 Of course, while reliance on philanthropy has some risks, so does reliance on governments and private companies. Drug companies generally direct research toward diseases of the wealthy countries. Governments can change course, as when administrations change, and programs can be tangled in politics or subject to corporate influence. 
 Philanthropies can try approaches that governments might not want to take or can help the development of drugs that pharmaceutical companies might not develop on their own. 
 Wealthy donors, for example, are now supporting much of the research on human embryonic stem cells in the United States because the Bush administration opposes the part of that work that results in the destruction of human embryos. 
 In California, foundations started by some of the state's wealthiest business executives are providing $14 million to the state's stem cell research program, while $3 billion in state funding is tied up in litigation.
 Charities can also move faster in some cases. The World Health Organization ''doesn't have the power to get massive amounts of things happening quickly,'' said Barry R. Bloom, dean of the Harvard School of Public Health, who has long been involved in W.H.O. activities.
 Mr. Bloom, who is working under a grant from the Gates Foundation to develop new vaccine technologies, said that organization can fashion more effective programs. 
 Philanthropy, to be sure, has long played a vital role in medicine, as it has in education, culture and other areas. In the early part of the 20th century, the Rockefeller Foundation essentially eradicated hookworm in the United States and developed a vaccine for yellow fever. 
 The Howard Hughes Medical Institute, founded in 1953, now supports about 300 university scientists. In Britain, the Wellcome Trust, founded in 1936, has long been a major backer of medical research and in recent years helped pay for the Human Genome Project. 
 One question is whether wealthy individuals should set up their own philanthropies or give money to existing organizations with experience. Mr. Buffett was praised last week by some experts for not creating a monument to himself. 
 But some philanthropists say they want to actively manage how their money is spent or do something not done by others. James and Virginia Stowers have put much of their fortune from starting American Century Investments, the mutual fund company, into creating the Stowers Institute for Medical Research, which opened in 2000 in Kansas City, Mo. 
 David Welte, an adviser to Mr. and Mrs. Stowers, said others had recommended that the couple -- both of them cancer survivors -- give their money to an existing institution because leading scientists might not want to move to Kansas City. But the couple were loyal to their city and also wanted to create a new type of research institute, more collegial and free of some of the bureaucratic tangles in universities, he said. 
 It is too early to judge the scientific track record of the institute, which does research on genes and cells. It has about 350 employees and an endowment of about $2 billion.
 Some experts say that the Gates Foundation is singularly influential, in part because of its vast resources and also because it deals with development of drugs for malaria, tuberculosis and other diseases that do not attract much attention from drug companies and other charities.
 ''You'd look 100 years previously to find someone as influential,'' said Eugene R. Tempel, executive director of the Center on Philanthropy at Indiana University, alluding to the early days of the Rockefeller Foundation. 
 In the United States, philanthropies generally provide less money toward a particular area of research than the government's National Institutes of Health, which has a budget of more than $28 billion a year. Drug and biotechnology companies spend tens of billions of dollars a year on research and development. 
 So philanthropies often try to achieve an effect by galvanizing more government spending and putting money into things the government or companies are not doing. 
 The Prostate Cancer Foundation, started by Mr. Milken, who had that disease, spends about $20 million a year on research on the disease compared with more than $500 million by the government and $1 billion by industry, said Leslie Michelson, its chief executive. 
 But the foundation and Mr. Milken's advocacy are generally credited with helping sharply increase government and academic activity in the field. And the foundation's annual conference has become a leading opportunity for scientists to share ideas and data. 
 Executives at foundations said they saw a growing role for themselves. The National Institutes of Health budget has been stagnant in the last few years and it is becoming harder for scientists to obtain government grants. Government grants, they say, also rarely go to scientists with radical ideas with a small chance of success. 
 Philanthropies are also becoming more directly involved in developing drugs, not just sponsoring academic research. Investors have become more cautious about backing early-stage biotechnology companies, preferring instead companies that already have drugs well into clinical trials. That has left a funding gap between academic research and later-stage drug development. 
 ''Our strategy is to be in that sweet spot,'' said Deborah Brooks, president of the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. The charity hopes to spend $25 million this year on research.
 Indeed, it seems business and philanthropy are converging into what is sometimes called venture philanthropy. The Epilepsy Therapy Development Project, a charity that has raised about $5 million, has invested in companies developing drugs for that disease, both to help the companies along and to reap a profit to spend on more research if a company becomes successful.
 One of the most active in drug development is the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. It has spent more than $100 million in the last few years screening chemicals to see if they would make drugs, helping to run some clinical trials and giving grants to biotechnology companies.
 ''We believe we have to reduce the risk of companies to come into the field of cystic fibrosis,'' which is a rare disease, said Robert J. Beall, chief executive of the foundation. The foundation has played some role in virtually all of the nearly 30 drugs in development for the disease. 
 Some philanthropists play very active roles. Hans-Werner Hector, a co-founder of the German software giant SAP, read a newspaper article in 2001 about the struggles of Therion Biologics, a Cambridge, Mass., company trying to raise money for development of a so-called cancer vaccine. He put in more than $100 million, or 90 percent, of the company's financing, and became its major shareholder, said Mark W. Leuchtenberger, chief executive. 
 Mr. Hector could have also profited from its success. But last week, Therion announced that its pancreatic cancer treatment failed to prolong lives. It is likely his money will, in effect, be a charitable gift after all.

HEADLINE: Drastic Action, Modest Result In New Jersey

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 7 

 BODY:
By shutting down the New Jersey government for nearly a week, Gov. Jon S. Corzine has shown his political rivals that he has the resolve to win a costly showdown with a Legislature grown accustomed to financing its spiraling spending by borrowing with abandon.
 But behind his stylistic victory over Democratic legislators, the budget plan Mr. Corzine forced through a battle-weary Legislature will probably have only a modest effect on the factors that have made New Jersey, one of the nation's richest states, one of the most fiscally troubled ones as well.
By increasing the state sales tax to 7 cents on the dollar from 6 cents, Mr. Corzine has tapped into a new stream of revenue that will raise about $1.1 billion a year and close this year's $4 billion budget shortfall. But at least half of that money will go toward property tax relief next year and possibly more in the years beyond that. And the sales tax increase will leave state leaders less flexibility to cope with next year's budget, when increases in retirees' health care costs, pension obligations and school financing are expected to present New Jersey with a gap of at least $2 billion. 
 So although some of Mr. Corzine's aides were crowing that the show of political resolve had marked his emergence as a first-rate arm-twister, the governor himself termed the agreement ''a halting first step.''
 As sleep-deprived legislators went through the process of drafting the budget agreement into law on Friday, Republicans here -- who as the minority party were essentially locked out of the debate -- were still startled at just how much trouble the Democrats went through.
 The impasse idled more than 100,000 workers and cost the state more than $3 million a day in lost revenue from closed casinos and halted lottery sales. It was believed to be the first time that a state government controlled by one-party rule had been shut down by such a struggle.
 And for all of the talk of Mr. Corzine's victory over his fellow Democratic lawmakers in the Assembly, Republicans were quick to point out that his prize was a political land mine -- a tax increase.
 ''They shut down the government in order to raise taxes,'' said State Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican from Hunterdon County who has earned a reputation for fiscal prudence by criticizing borrowing by both parties. ''There's still going to be a structural deficit. It's hardly a good day for the citizens of New Jersey.''
 As much as some Republicans have clearly enjoyed the spectacle of Democrats battling with one another, the budget problems that greeted Mr. Corzine when he took office in January were a bipartisan creation. Over the past 10 years, governors and legislative leaders from both parties have relied on a variety of borrowing schemes to avoid tax increases while spending more and more.
 While other states used the low interest rates of the past several years to free up money by refinancing debt, New Jersey has gone on the equivalent of a borrowing spree. 
 For instance, the state borrowed against its proceeds from the tobacco settlement, and against future toll collections on the public highways. Now, with other states now reaping the benefits of their frugality and an improved economy, New Jersey finds itself saddled with costly interest payments and few attractive borrowing gimmicks left. Indeed, a study in the spring by the National Conference of State Legislatures found that 42 states were expecting a surplus.
 ''In 11 states, the state government cannot take on general obligation debt and in other places, culturally, it's unacceptable to borrow, so if they want to build a road or a new school they pay up front, in cash,'' said Arturo Perez, a budget specialist for the conference. ''But New Jersey isn't one of those places, and over the past few years, the way that power to borrow has been used has led them to where they are today.''
 For all the anger that some New Jerseyeans have expressed this week about silent slot machines and padlocked state parks, many of the most shortsighted fiscal decisions over the past decade were devised, in part, to avoid rekindling the fury some residents unleashed in 1990, when Gov. Jim Florio called for sweeping increases in the sales and income taxes. Outraged demonstrators converged on the State House and emblazoned Mr. Florio's likeness on rolls of bathroom tissue to protest the proposed levy on paper products.
 Mr. Florio dropped the paper tax, but won a Pyrrhic victory by forcing a $2.8 billion increase through the Legislature. In the years to come, antitax groups harnessed that anger and ousted Democrats from power in both the Assembly and the State Senate. 
 Then, in the 1993 campaign for governor, Christie Whitman, a Republican, swept Mr. Florio out of office with a pledge to slash the state's income tax.
 Mrs. Whitman made good on that promise, but rather than pay for those tax reductions solely with spending cuts, her administration found creative ways to borrow. The most notable was her plan to issue $2.8 billion in bonds in 1997 to keep the pension system afloat. In the short term, the move allowed the state to plug a $590 million budget hole and reap benefits from the surging equities market. 
 But the drop in the market after the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, took the luster off the deal, and the bonds have cost far more in interest payments than they have earned.
 When Mrs. Whitman left for a cabinet position in Washington in 2001, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco served out the remainder of her term as an acting governor and, in a gesture that won favor of the state workers' unions in a legislative election year, granted a 9 percent increase in pension benefits.
 When the next campaign for governor came along, James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate, seized on public unease with the Republicans' fiscal management and promised to end the ''runaway spending and reckless borrowing.''
 Once in office, Mr. McGreevey accelerated both and relied on a bevy of one-time gimmicks to keep the state afloat.
 After two years of modest growth in spending, Mr. McGreevey's final budget in 2004 bulged with a 17 percent increase, and was financed by a $2 billion borrowing plan. The State Supreme Court, in ruling that the plan was in violation of New Jersey's constitutional mandate for a balanced budget, allowed it that year but said similar methods could not be used again.
 The state's debt -- which increased to $15.7 billion from $4 billion in the 1990's -- jumped to $28 billion while Mr. McGreevey was in office. The cost of New Jersey's annual debt service rose to $2.1 billion from $1.45 billion, and Wall Street twice lowered the state's credit rating.
 Robin Prunty, an analyst from Standard & Poor's, said New Jersey's budget problems are a culmination of years of trying to forestall the inevitable and that with the new budget, Mr. Corzine has begun trying to turn the state toward fiscal responsibility.
 ''In many other states they took a more balanced approach to the problem when there was a fiscal downturn, by doing a mixture of spending cuts, revenue increases and nonrecurring income,'' said Ms. Prunty, a director of public finance. ''New Jersey relied more heavily on the nonrecurring income which, of course, just pushes the problem off until next year. And this is what next year looks like.''
 So what about next year? 
 With pension and health care costs rising, the state will probably face another lean budget year and Mr. Corzine will again be forced to choose between more tax increases or painful spending cuts. But even some Republicans acknowledge that Mr. Corzine has changed the terms of Trenton's budget debate by facing down his Democratic rivals and halting the state's reliance on debt and fiscal sleight-of-hand.
 ''I think it also sets a tone for the remainder of Corzine's term,'' said Carl Golden, a spokesman for two Republican governors, Thomas H. Kean and Ms. Whitman, who now does political communications and consulting work. ''He may be new to all of this, but he's going to be firm and very resolute for what he believes in.''

HEADLINE: Tensions Grow Over Mexico Vote as Opposition Plans Rally Today

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and GINGER THOMPSON; Elisabeth Malkin contributed reporting for this article.

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 7 

 BODY:
Mexico hung in limbo on Friday, as tensions rose between those seeking a recount in the presidential race and those seeking to accept Felipe Calderon as the winner and move on.
 After a tally showed that the two top candidates were separated by 243,000 votes, the election has exposed deep divides in society, along class and regional lines. The voting has put the strength of the young democracy to its toughest test.
A day after election officials said Mr. Calderon, an advocate of free trade, had won the narrowest of victories, the country seemed more on edge than on a high. 
 Supporters of Mr. Calderon's leftist rival, Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, girded for fights in court and on the streets, beginning with a rally scheduled for Saturday. Mr. Calderon's supporters and allies called on Mr. Lopez Obrador to concede defeat for the good of the country. 
 The uncertainty caused consternation among citizens of all political persuasions.
 ''This man Lopez Obrador makes people afraid, and his worst fault is that he lies to people and can stir up violence,'' said Sandra Sanchez, 38, a designer who voted for Mr. Calderon. ''He should recognize his defeat already, because if he says he defends the people, he should know the people don't want to fight.''
 Consuelo Castillo Guerrero, 63, an impeccably dressed retired saleswoman, plans to march in support of Mr. Lopez Obrador. ''We want absolute transparency, because we're not convinced,'' Ms. Castillo said. ''I think that if things were as clean as they say, then what's the inconvenience of recounting?''
 The White House was quick to support Mr. Calderon. President Bush called to congratulate him in the early afternoon for receiving the largest number of votes, even though he had not officially been declared president-elect. Mexican law requires the electoral court to ratify the results. 
 ''The president also noted the solid foundation of the U.S.-Mexican relationship and his confidence in Mexican democratic institutions,'' said Frederick Jones, a spokesman for the National Security Council.
 The European Union said Friday that there was no evidence of major fraud or irregularity in the election, Reuters reported. Election observers, who visited a third of the country's 300 electoral districts during voting last Sunday, ''did not report incidents or irregularities that could cloud the transparency of the counting process or affect the results,'' said Ignacio Salafranca, head of the European Union team.
 Mr. Calderon took the role of president-elect on Friday in a meeting with foreign correspondents. He discussed plans to improve relations with the rest of Latin America, to strengthen the commitment to human rights and to making the country a magnet for investment to help generate jobs and keep Mexicans from migrating to the United States.
 When asked about the polarization that threatens to undermine confidence in his government, Mr. Calderon, 43, said he would work to rebuild relations among his rivals in Mr. Lopez Obrador's Democratic Revolutionary Party. Mr. Calderon also made clear that he was prepared to use his National Action Party's new plurality in Congress to sway support from other parties and govern without Mr. Lopez Obrador's party if it tries to block him.
 Mr. Calderon said he was not worried about a legal challenge to the election because most evidence indicated that he had won the most transparent presidential election in Mexican history. He said the irregularities found in the first count were minor. And he made clear that he would not support a new count.
 ''This is a plural country,'' he said. ''And everyone's first responsibility, especially mine, is reconciliation.'' Mr. Calderon said he received a congratulatory call on Sunday from President Vicente Fox, who has withheld public comment on the election. Congratulations came from governments that included Canada and Spain, as well as the United States. 
 The Mexican stock market seesawed all week as the news changed. By the end of the week, it had gained 3.6 percent. Wall Street analysts agreed that Mr. Calderon's victory seemed unassailable, but warned investors to settle in for a long wait until the election was confirmed.
 The United States ambassador here, Antonio O. Garza, wrote that although the electoral process was not complete, ''I believe the actions of Mexico's current administration and the political parties, and the transparency of the I.F.E., have not only strengthened civic pride, but assured Mexico of its place in the world as a prime example of the world's strong and vital democracies.''
 The I.F.E., or Federal Electoral Institute, runs the elections.
 Mr. Lopez Obrador, who has made a career of challenging elections, prepared to try to prove that the electoral system remained flawed. His case before the Federal Electoral Tribunal could delay declaring a new president until September.
 Advisers to Mr. Lopez Obrador, a former mayor of Mexico City, said he would challenge the results in one-third of the 130,000 polling places, focusing on sites with many null votes or where his party did not have representatives to oversee the count.
 The advisers acknowledged that the errors found in each ballot box opened in the final count were small, but argued that together they could add up to enough votes to change the result. 
 ''If they recount the votes and Calderon wins by one vote, then it ends,'' said Mayor-Elect Marcelo Ebrard of Mexico City, a close adviser to Mr. Lopez Obrador. ''If they don't count the votes, there will always be a doubt.''
 If the court does not order a recount, Mr. Lopez Obrador left little doubt at a news conference on Thursday that he was considering mass marches as a next step. ''It's our right,'' he said.
 Rumbling beneath the confidence in one camp and outrage in the other was a debate on whether the most competitive elections in Mexican history had been good or bad. For some people, the cascade of results raised ghosts from a not-too-distant past when the state manipulated elections. Other people feared that if Mexico continued to bow to the old ghosts, it would never break free of them.
 About the only thing that seemed clear was that Mexico has been polarized. Speaking randomly to average Calderon supporters and then to people who support Mr. Lopez Obrador was like playing hopscotch across the gaping economic divide.
 Manuel Arango, a wealthy real estate developer who is active in philanthropies, echoed the feelings of many supporters of Mr. Calderon when he said, ''I hope that everything plays out within the institutions and not on the street.''
 Juan Huerta, 55, who works at a newsstand near a luxury department store, said he thought that the election was riddled with fraud. Mr. Huerta said he tried to cast a ballot for Mr. Lopez Obrador, but was told that rain had soaked all the ballots. ''This is a fraud against the people,'' he said.
 ''The PAN is playing with the country's social peace'' he added about the governing party. ''If there's violence, then so be it. People are fed up. That's why they had the revolution.''

HEADLINE: How to Be a Good Neighbor

BYLINE: By Greg Grandin. 
Greg Grandin, a professor of history at New York University, is the author of ''Empire's Workshop: Latin America, the United States and the Rise of the New Imperialism.''

DATELINE: Miami 

 BODY:
THE Aztecs used to believe that history is not linear but circular, with great events repeating themselves on a regular basis. That certainly seems to be the case with Mexico, which has a revolution once every hundred years. 
 In 1810, peasants thrown off their land by plantation owners led a violent five-year rebellion that paved the way for Mexico's independence from Spain. In 1910, an instance of electoral fraud ignited an agrarian revolution, which in turn kicked off a decade-long civil war in which millions of Mexicans died.
Nearly a century later, Mexico's current electoral crisis likewise is propelled by rural unrest -- this time largely brought about by the anger of agricultural workers displaced by the North American Free Trade Agreement. Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, the center-left presidential candidate who is contesting the declared victory of Felipe Calderon in last Sunday's election, draws much of his support from this increasingly restive population of rural poor. 
 Before Nafta, Mexico was self-sufficient in corn and bean production. Today, one out of three Mexican tortillas is made with cheap corn meal from the United States. In 1993, more than 10 million Mexicans made their living off the land. Today, even as Mexico's population has grown, that number has plummeted to about seven million. 
 Mexican farmers simply can't compete with capital-intensive United States agribusiness, which continues to enjoy generous government subsidies. Moreover, Mexican commodity importers receive low-interest loans to buy crops from the United States. Every year, nearly three million tons of harvested Mexican corn is left to rot because it is too expensive to sell.
 Mexicans have reason to worry that this is not all the trouble Nafta has in store. In 2008, the agreement's final provision is set to go into effect, eliminating the last tariffs on United States corn and beans and ending the subsidies Mexico gives to its peasant farmers -- all the while leaving untouched the far larger subsidies Washington doles out to its own agricultural sector. During his campaign, Mr. Lopez Obrador pledged to renegotiate this provision, but J. B. Penn, the United States undersecretary of agriculture, last month pre-emptively responded by saying that ''we have no interest in renegotiating any parts of the agreement.''
 For the last decade and a half, Washington and its allies in Mexican politics, including Mr. Calderon, have promoted a free-trade economic model that has failed to deliver the prosperity its advocates promised. Although the Mexican economy grew by 3 percent last year, the country's poverty and inequality indicators remain typical to bad by Latin American standards, with the richest 10 percent of citizens controlling 43 percent of the country's wealth, while some 40 percent of Mexicans live below the poverty line. 
 These problems, combined with Mexican anger over the immigration debate in the United States, run the risk of souring relations between our two countries for the foreseeable future.
 But there is a way the Bush administration can help to set things on a different course. Although election officials say Mr. Calderon won the presidential vote, the United States should not rush to embrace him as the election's victor. The official tally gives Mr. Calderon a razor-thin lead, and there are credible reports of significant irregularities that could, at best, weaken the legitimacy of a Calderon presidency, and at worst, lead to escalating protests. The disputed votes include the 904,000 annulled ballots that come primarily from regions that went heavily for Mr. Lopez Obrador, as well as discrepancies between the numbers handed in by polling stations and the actual ballots cast.
 The best thing the United States can do now is to support the push for a recount and to refrain from calling on Mr. Lopez Obrador to concede. Then, no matter who finally wins the election, the White House should renegotiate Nafta, allowing Mexico to set its own policy in support of its rural economy. If the Bush administration does otherwise, it might help begin yet another season of Mexican upheaval -- just as the Aztecs might have predicted.

HEADLINE: Justices Tacitly Backed Use Of Guantanamo, Bush Says

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7 

 BODY:
In his most detailed comments to date on the Supreme Court's rejection of his decision to put detainees on trial before military commissions, President Bush said Friday that the court had tacitly approved his use of the detention center at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. 
 ''It didn't say we couldn't have done -- couldn't have made that decision, see?'' Mr. Bush said at a news conference in Chicago. ''They were silent on whether or not Guantanamo -- whether or not we should have used Guantanamo. In other words, they accepted the use of Guantanamo, the decision I made.''
Mr. Bush's remarks put a favorable spin on a ruling that has been widely interpreted as a rebuke of the administration's policies in the war on terror. The court, ruled broadly last week in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld that military commissions were unauthorized by statute and violated international law.
 The question of whether Mr. Bush had properly used Guantanamo Bay to house detainees was not at issue in the case. At issue was whether the president could unilaterally establish military commissions with rights different from those allowed at a court-martial to try detainees for war crimes.
 Mr. Bush has said since the ruling that he will work with Congress to figure out how to use military commissions to try detainees, a promise he repeated on Friday in Chicago.
 ''I am willing to abide by the ruling of the Supreme Court,'' the president said.
 The Chicago news conference, which featured local reporters asking the president questions alongside the regular members of the White House press corps, was designed by the White House to give the president more exposure in the country at a time when his poll numbers are declining and Americans are uneasy with his leadership on the economy and the war in Iraq.
 But members of the Chicago press did not serve up softball questions. The issue of Mr. Bush's polls came up when a reporter asked about a fund-raiser the president planned to attend for Judy Baar Topinka, the Republican candidate for Illinois governor. 
 ''An aide to Judy Topinka was quoted as saying that given your low approval ratings in the polls, they prefer you to come here in the middle of the night,'' the reporter said.
 ''Didn't work,'' Mr. Bush replied. ''I'm coming to lunch.''
 The president also gave an endorsement of sorts to Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the special prosecutor who handled a leak investigation involving Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief political adviser.
 Mr. Bush said Mr. Fitzgerald, who is also the United States attorney in Chicago, had done a ''very professional job'' in handling the leak investigation, which resulted in the indictment of I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney. Mr. Rove was not indicted.

HEADLINE: Leftist Candidate of Mexican Elections Claims Fraud

BYLINE: By JAMES C. MCKINLEY AND GINGER THOMPSON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 8 

 BODY:
While the announced winner of last Sundays presidential election, Felipe Calderon, kept a low profile Saturday, his leftist rival hardened his position that the poll had been marred by fraud and suggesting there would be instability without a vote-by-vote recount.
 If there is not democracy, Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador said during a press conference on Saturday, there will be instability. 
Aides to Mr. Calderon said that after a whirlwind schedule of meetings and appearances on Friday including a stop in at ceremonies for his childrens last day of classes the former energy minister was taking the day off Saturday. While Mr. Calderon had begun to give out hints of how he would approach issues like trade, globalization and dealings with the United States on immigration, his day off allowed Mr. Lopez Obrador to claim the spotlight.
 Hours before he was scheduled to lead a rally in Mexicos central plaza, the Zocalo, Mr. Lopez Obrador said that his rival was wrong to begin assuming the role of president-elect before the results of last Sundays contests had been upheld in court. And Mr. Lopez Obrador objected to the congratulatory messages that had been sent to Mr. Calderon from the United States, Spain and Canada. He said it was all part of a strategy by Mr. Calderon to end a process that was not yet over.
 They want to turn the page, but things are not that way, Mr. Lopez Obrador said. This is just started.
 Meeting with foreign reporters on Friday afternoon, Mr. Calderon seemed confident that Mr. Lopez Obradors legal challenges would not stand up in court.
 My triumph is clear and definitive, Mr. Calderon said. There are no legal elements that sustain the possibility of a complaint. In this election, the votes have already been counted, vote by vote, at the time they should have been counted, at the closing of the polls, as happens in all the world.
 Mr. Lopez Obrador, in a meeting Saturday with foreign reporters, said that the pending rally was the first of several actions he would take to demand a recount of the 41 million votes cast last Sunday. The Federal Electoral Institute announced the final tally of votes on Thursday, saying that Mr. Calderon, of the conservative National Action Party, had won by a narrow margin of 243,000 votes.
 Mr. Lopez Obrador, of the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party, has said he would challenge those results at the Federal Electoral Tribunal. He has until Monday to present his case to the magistrates. On Saturday, he planned to take his case to the people.John M. Ackerman, an expert on electoral laws at that National Autonomous University of Mexico, said that many of Mexicos electoral laws are so new and, and therefore untested, that it is hard to assess Mr. Lopez Obradors chances are for successfully challenging the election results. The electoral tribunal was empowered in 1996 to validate presidential elections, and in the only other election since, in 2000, Vicente Fox handily defeated the Institutional Revolutionary Party.
 Mr. Ackerman said that in the tribunals short history, it had ordered broad though not complete recounts in state and local elections. The largest recount, he said, was six years ago in the state of Jalisco, where the race was so tight and fiercely contested that the state was compared to Florida.
 Mr. Ackerman also said that the magistrates had not hesitated to reverse decisions by the Federal Electoral Institute.
 In this last election alone, Mr. Ackerman said, the tribunal overruled at least two of the electoral institutes decisions, and ordered ads by Mr. Calderon and by President Fox taken off the air, after judging it as either inflammatory or unfair.
 Mr. Lopez Obrador led two volatile demonstrations in 1994 to protest his loss in the governors race in his home state of Tabasco. Mr. Lopez Obrador accused the former Institutional Revolutionary Party of spending millions more on its campaign than was legal and of fraud at the polls.
 In this campaign, Mr. Calderons campaign used that history to argue that Mr. Lopez Obradors could be a danger to Mexico. And several political analysts have said that Mr. Lopez Obradors behavior since Thursday have proven Mr. Calderon right.
 What marks Lopez Obradors attitude is not the construction of democracy, nor the consolidation of his own political force, but an evident ambition for personal power, wrote Jorge Fernandez Menendez, an investigative journalist and political commentator. If it was said that Lopez Obrador was messianic, he is confirming it with each one of his acts since Sunday.
 At the same time,, in the daily newspaper Excelsior, Jose Antonio Crespo wrote in favor of a recount.
 If I were Felipe Calderon, I would try to legitimize my electoral victory, he wrote. That way, I would gain full recognition of my future presidency, taking away from the PRD all of its arguments for questioning my victory, narrow, but genuine. After the Thursday announcement, Mr. Calderon and some of his aides began publicly addressing some policy issues. Arturo Sarukan, a foreign policy adviser to Mr. Calderon, said Mr. Calderon intended to put Mexico at the center of the regions debate over globalization. Political analysts have suggested that a Calderon presidency could signal an end to the advance of leftwing politics across Latin America, as neoliberal economic policies from Washington have fallen from favor.
 We will lead the debate on how Latin America will keep competitive in the world, how to keep it from losing ground to Asia, Mr. Sarukan said. We have to figure out how to demonstrate to our societies that free markets, transparency and democracy really can deliver the goods for all.
 Mr. Calderon would seem a certain ally for the United States, and in his press conference with foreign reporters on Friday, said he would not seek to renegotiate agricultural clauses of the North American Free Trade Agreement. I dont see broad probabilities that the winner of such a negotiation would be Mexico, he said.
 On immigration, Mr. Calderon said he would urge the United States and Canada to join with Mexico to create a fund for the construction of infrastructure and other development projects to generate jobs in high-migration states in Mexico like Mr. Calderons home state of Michoacan that would keep people home.
 The solution to migration is not walls, Mr. Calderon said. The only real solution to stop or slow the migration phenomenon is the generation of good-paying jobs.
 He added, I continue to argue that un kilometer of highway in Zacatecasor Michoacan, can do more to reduce migration than 10 kilometers of wall in Texas or Arizona.
 And that is something we need to understand on both sides of the border.

HEADLINE: Mittal Announces Plan for Steel Plant in India 

BYLINE: By AMELIA GENTLEMAN and HEATHER TIMMONS; Amelia Gentleman reported from New Delhi for this article and Heather Timmons from London.

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, July 7 

 BODY:
Fresh from winning the fight for the European steel company Arcelor, Lakshmi Mittal visited India on Friday and said he planned to invest as much as $9 billion in a steel plant in an impoverished eastern area of the country.
 Mr. Mittal said that Mittal Steel, based in Rotterdam, would invest 300 billion to 400 billion rupees ($6.7 billion to $9 billion) to build a steel plant in the mineral-rich state of Orissa. The plant, to be built in two phases, would be one of India's largest, with a capacity of 12 million tons a year. 
 After making his bid for Arcelor in January, Mr. Mittal was roundly criticized by Arcelor executives for his company's practice of relying on low-cost production in emerging markets.
 Analysts said that Mr. Mittal's plans for Orissa were another sign that the overall industry was headed in that direction.
 ''The steel industry really doesn't belong in developed countries any longer; it belongs in developing countries,'' said Roger Nightingale, global economic adviser for Millennium Global Investments in London.
 Mittal Steel spent nearly six months trying to win over Arcelor, and in June the companies finally agreed to a deal valued at 26.5 billion euros ($33 billion). Mr. Mittal said he would thank the Indian prime minister, Manmohan Singh, for his support during his visit to India.
 ''We want to be partners with the growth in India,'' Mr. Mittal said.
 Analysts forecast that demand for steel in India would rise as the country's economy booms, with strong growth in the automobile and construction sectors.
 ''Everyone seems to want a foothold in India,'' said Peter Fish, managing director of Meps International, a consulting firm. Demand for steel in India is high, and the country is rich in iron ore.
 Mr. Mittal may be trying to capitalize on the momentum from his successful deal with Arcelor to get further support for steel projects in India, said Daniel Altman, an analyst with Bear Stearns in New York.
 Mittal Steel already had plans to build a $9 billion steel plant in the neighboring state of Jharkhand, but Mr. Mittal said he was unhappy with the slow pace of negotiations there and was concerned about the poor infrastructure. 
 In India, state governments, not national officials, approve the construction of steel plants, and that support has been difficult to secure. 
 The announcement Friday that Mittal was planning a plant in Orissa might be an attempt to pressure the governments in Jharkhand and in Orissa to smooth the approval process, analysts said.
 ''I think they are playing one state against the other,'' Mr. Altman said.
 Posco, a South Korean steel company, has also been negotiating with Orissa's government to build a plant there. Those negotiations have been going slowly, Mr. Altman said.
 Expansion into India would not threaten jobs in Europe or elsewhere, Mr. Mittal stressed.
 ''When we announced the deal with Arcelor, we said that there would be no job cuts'' he said. ''There will be absolutely no repercussions on jobs in Europe or anywhere else in the group.'' 
 That may not be true in the future, analysts cautioned. 
 ''That's certainly going to be valid in the short term, but what happens in the long term is anybody's guess,'' Mr. Nightingale said.
 Mittal will ''keep Arcelor's facilities in Europe, especially the highest-quality steel facilities and those serving the motor industry,'' Mr. Nightingale predicted, but a lot of Mittal's other products will come from plants elsewhere.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Lakshmi Mittal, right, and his son Aditya were in India yesterday to announce an investment in a steel plant. (Photo by Manish Swarup/Associated Press)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A St. Petersburg Story

 BODY:
Russia's meeting on July 15 with leaders of the world's richest democracies requires an important historical footnote. President Vladimir Putin will welcome the Group of Eight to St. Petersburg, where leaders are expected to talk about energy, Iran and terrorism. It is an event that would have appealed to Peter the Great, who built his beautiful but extravagant city over 300 years ago to win Russia a place at the European tables of his day. 
 Now it is Mr. Putin's turn to put Russia's post-Soviet power and progress on display. But the international acceptance that Mr. Putin craves will quickly disappear if the Kremlin continues its march toward what critics call a ''staged democracy'' instead of a real one.
 The list of concerns has grown steadily during Mr. Putin's stewardship. The exuberant free press that erupted after the end of the Soviet Union 15 years ago is mostly gone now, and what passes for news increasingly comes straight from the Kremlin fax machine. National television networks now labor under the president's thumb, and the best newspapers are falling into line as well. The Internet, smaller publications and radio broadcasts are still exempt, but many Russian journalists fear it may be only a matter of time.
 Then there are the upcoming presidential election in 2008. Mr. Putin's term is up, and he has said he will step down as required by law. But there are already troubling signs that if his loyal Parliament cannot find a way to keep him on, it will anoint his choice for successor. And woe unto any candidate who doesn't have the Kremlin's seal of approval.
 Hopes for a rule of law are also dimming as the judicial system lands hardest on those out of favor with the Kremlin. Non-government organizations that sometimes criticize the government now see the Kremlin turning on them as well. Organizations like the Moscow Helsinki Group have come under attack for criticizing Mr. Putin's record on human rights and the treatment of ethnic minorities. 
 In the name of fighting extremism, Mr. Putin's government has enacted a new law that can easily be used to harass almost any activists who criticize the powerful. And one of Mr. Putin's TV stations falsely accused four important groups, including Moscow Helsinki, of taking money from British spies. This is a familiar tactic in Russia that should have been retired with the Soviet flag.
 Mr. Putin's Russia is still far better than it was during the bleak decades of Communism. And Russia clearly has the economic clout to sit with France, Germany, Japan, the United States, Britain, Canada and Italy. But the leaders of this club need to make it clear to Russia that membership demands not only the power of wealth but also a democratic government to go with it.
