HEADLINE: Now, Add the North Korean Wild Card to the Mix

BYLINE: By Mark A. Stein

 BODY:
IT was a rough week for crystal-ball gazers. Almost as soon as economists forecast that the economy might continue to grow at a relatively healthy pace in the second half, a steady drip of pessimistic news began to dribble out. And then North Korea provocatively test-fired a phalanx of guided missiles despite warnings from the major powers to desist; stocks fell and oil prices rose as tensions grew.

TOBACCO VICTORY -- The Florida Supreme Court upheld a decision to toss out a $145 billion judgment against tobacco companies, ruling that smokers' cases ''are highly individualized'' and ''do not lend themselves to class-action treatment.''
The decision is a crushing blow to plaintiffs' lawyers, who have pushed for large class-action cases with the potential for multibillion-dollar verdicts. Smokers must now sue one by one, a daunting prospect against big corporations able to mount protracted, and costly, court fights. 
 Investors applauded the decision in Florida, which sharply reduces the possibility of large bank-breaking awards in tobacco cases. In December, the Supreme Court of Illinois threw out a $10 billion judgment against Philip Morris USA in a class-action consumer fraud suit that accused the company of deceiving smokers by marketing its ''light'' cigarettes as having lower levels of tar and nicotine.
 The next big decision, expected in a few months, will come in a federal civil racketeering case filed by the Justice Department against several large cigarette makers and seeking damages of $14 billion over 10 years as well as fines if youth smoking rates do not decline.

TAKING RESPONSIBILITY -- Reeling from production delays for Airbus's flagship A380 superjumbo jet and an investigation into possible insider trading, the co-chief executive of Europe's biggest aerospace company resigned. The man in charge of commercial aircraft manufacturing also stepped down.
 Noel Forgeard, the co-chief of the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, and Gustav Humbert, the chief executive of its commercial aircraft division, Airbus, resigned under pressure from their largest shareholders, including Lagardere of France and DaimlerChrysler of Germany.
 The company said a six-month delay in delivery of A380's would reduce earnings by $2.6 billion over the next four years.
 Mr. Forgeard was also under fire for having sold $2.5 million worth of EADS stock shortly before DaimlerChrysler and Lagardere said that they would reduce their stakes in the company, and three months before news of the A380 delay became public. He has denied wrongdoing.
 BAE, a British aerospace company, has called for an independent investigation of the affair, which has derailed its plan to sell its 20 percent stake in EADS.

SIGNS OF A SLOWDOWN -- Manufacturing and construction both grew at slower rates than expected last month, affirming the belief of some economists that a long series of interest rate increases by the Fed has succeeded in cooling overall economic growth.
 If that slowdown is reflected in wholesale and retail prices, the Fed may stop raising rates and start calculating when it can start to cut them again. 
 The Institute for Supply Management, an industry group in Tempe, Ariz., reported the slower growth in manufacturing in June while the Commerce Department noted that construction spending had declined for the second consecutive month -- the first time that has happened in more than three years. 
 Some economists said manufacturing could perk up in the months ahead if the Fed stops raising rates because that could cause the dollar to fall in value, making American goods cheaper abroad.

SLUMPING SALES -- Evidence of how unevenly the manufacturing slump is hitting companies came in the form of monthly auto sales. General Motors' sales fell 25.7 percent last month, hammered by high gas prices and the absence of the rebates and other subsidies that lifted sales last year. Toyota's sales, meanwhile, rose 14.4 percent.
 Ominously for American manufacturers, stubbornly high gasoline prices, which have already crimped sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles, have begun to curb sales of equally profitable pickup trucks. G.M.'s truck sales fell 37 percent in June, while Ford said sales of its light trucks dropped 14.6 percent.
 G.M. is weighing a proposal by Kirk Kerkorian, one of its biggest shareholders, to discuss a possible alliance with Renault, the French automaker, and Nissan Motor, the No. 3 Japanese automaker. Renault owns a controlling stake in Nissan.

STILL HIGHER GAS -- Worries about tensions between Iran and the West, combined with production difficulties along the Gulf Coast of the United States, propelled oil prices to as much as $75.78 a barrel -- a nominal record, though still below historical highs when adjusted for inflation.
 Analysts said the spike could push the national average price of regular unleaded gasoline above $3 a gallon. The last time the national average exceeded $3 was when Hurricanes Katrina and Rita shut refineries in Louisiana and Texas.
 A weekly survey of gasoline inventories next Wednesday could drive prices further if the stockpile has not risen as the country gets deeper into the summer driving season.

A SHOCKING DEATH -- Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive of Enron who was convicted of fraud and conspiracy in the company's collapse, died of a heart attack while on vacation in Colorado.
 Mr. Lay, known for his close ties to President Bush, was convicted on May 25 on six counts of fraud and conspiracy and four counts of bank fraud, and was free on a $5 million bond while awaiting his sentencing. Mr. Lay, 64, faced the possibility of spending the rest of his life in prison.
 Mr. Lay's unexpected death may have spared his survivors financial ruin by effectively voiding the guilty verdict against him, temporarily thwarting the federal government's efforts to seize his remaining real estate and financial assets, legal experts say.

HEADLINE: How 3 Managers Turned Back a Tide

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
THE few stock mutual funds that made money in the second quarter did so in a variety of ways, some by putting big chunks of their portfolios into cash, others by concentrating on energy, financial or media stocks. Managers at three of the best-performing funds spoke recently about their stocks, their strategies and what they see ahead for the market.

Defensive Strategies
 The $2.8 billion Federated Market Opportunity fund used several defensive strategies to earn its 5.4 percent return for the quarter. The fund is 28 percent in cash, 47 percent in short-term government notes and bills and, as a hedge, 4 percent in put options on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The rest is in stocks. ''I'm really focused on not losing money,'' said Steven J. Lehman, 49, who describes himself as a ''defensive contrarian value manager.'' 
 Mr. Lehman looks for what he calls ''cheap, overlooked and unpopular stocks.'' But he cautioned that while the fund made money on several stocks, its overall return was positive because of its cash and its options hedge, which allowed it to weather broad declines in domestic share prices and the dollar.
 Among the fund's profitable stocks was EnCana, of Calgary, Alberta, an oil and gas company whose shares trade on the New York Stock Exchange. Its shares rose 12.9 percent in the quarter. ''The stock price had been depressed,'' Mr. Lehman said, ''and it rebounded along with many other energy stocks.''
 The fund also made money on Boots, the big retail drugstore chain in Britain, whose local shares were up 10.5 percent. ''The company has had disappointing results in the past few years,'' Mr. Lehman said. ''With new management, I think its prospects are improving.'' The fund owns American depository receipts as well as shares traded in London.
 Another winner was Daiichi-Sankyo, a Japanese pharmaceutical manufacturer. ''The stock was cheap and unpopular because it didn't have an exciting array of new drugs coming down the road,'' he said. 
 He says investors now recognize that shares were oversold. The stock, which trades in Tokyo, rose 17.3 percent.
 Looking ahead at the overall stock market, Mr. Lehman said, ''I see bad things.'' He said that the market ''is overdue for a correction.'' 

A Focus on Energy
 Energy stocks helped drive the returns of the $2.3 billion CGM Focus fund, which rose 4.5 percent.
 The manager, G. Kenneth Heebner, 65, has invested half the portfolio in oil services companies, refining companies and oil and gas producers. He also had 39 percent in metals and mining companies at the end of the quarter. 
 ''We look for companies where the earnings pattern is going to cause strong relative price performance,'' Mr. Heebner said. 
 Because the fund holds just 22 stocks, its performance can be more volatile than that of more diversified portfolios. 
 One winner was Tenaris of Luxembourg. The fund owns the company's American depository receipts, which rose 13.3 percent. The company is a leading worldwide producer of welded alloy casing for oil wells, as well as other industrial steel pipe products. ''Their business has been extremely strong because of rising drilling activity in a high-oil-price environment,'' Mr. Heebner said. 
 The fund also made money in United States Steel, based in Pittsburgh. ''Steel prices have been rising this quarter, reflecting the strength in the global economy,'' Mr. Heebner said. ''U.S. Steel has been raising prices, creating a robust earnings outlook in this environment.'' Its shares rose 15.8 percent.
 Shares of Allegheny Technologies, also based in Pittsburgh, were up 13.3 percent. ''The stock's appreciation,'' he said, ''reflects robust demand and rising prices globally for stainless and alloy steels.'' 
 As for the future, he said, ''I think that the outlook for the global economy is very strong, and the U.S. economy, although it may slow down, will continue to grow.'' He cautions, however, that he considers the stock market ''fairly priced.'' 

Seeking 'a Margin of Safety'
 Financial services and media stocks propelled the returns of the $2.7 billion Weitz Value fund, up 2.6 percent, and the $1.8 billion Weitz Partners Value fund, up 2.4 percent. The manager, Wally Weitz, 57, looks for growing businesses that generate excess cash. ''We look for management that we trust to allocate the cash well,'' he said, ''and we try to buy earnings at prices low enough that we have a margin of safety.'' 
 Financial services companies performed strongly this quarter, he said, because of ''the perception that the Federal Reserve might be finished raising interest rates.'' 
 One winner was Redwood Trust, in Mill Valley, Calif., a mortgage real estate investment trust whose shares rose 14.4 percent. ''They have been positioning themselves very defensively, so earnings had dropped in the last couple of years,'' Mr. Weitz said. Shares performed strongly this quarter because ''the market is now realizing that earnings are likely to turn around this year and go back up again.''
 The fund also made money on Countrywide Financial, which was up 4.1 percent. Countrywide Financial, a mortgage lender, also has other financial services operations. As the refinancing boom began to slow, ''the stock price generally moved sideways,'' Mr. Weitz said. ''But now the perception is that the company is doing well.''
 A third profitable stock was Comcast, the cable and media company based in Philadelphia. Its shares rose 25.2 percent.
 ''The company has been doing fine for a long time even though its stock price has been weak,'' he said. Fears of competition from satellite and telecommunications companies are ''overdone,'' he said. 
 Mr. Weitz is cautious looking ahead. ''I wouldn't be surprised to see some pretty sharp market volatility, with a correction now and then,'' he said. ''I think the market is somewhat fragile.''

HEADLINE: Drink, Smoke and Gamble, and This Fund Climbs

BYLINE: By JOSHUA BROCKMAN

 BODY:
MORE than 150 mutual funds call themselves socially responsible, investing only in companies that meet a series of ethical standards set by their fund managers. Then there's the Vice Fund.
 Its prospectus says it favors ''products or services often considered socially irresponsible.'' The fund has fulfilled that promise under several different fund managers, investing mainly in companies involved with alcohol, tobacco, gambling and military contracting. This politically incorrect approach has helped the Vice Fund outperform the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index from its inception in 2002. But the fund has had more than its share of management turmoil.
In 2003 and 2004, civil and criminal charges were brought against three executives of the fund's former adviser, Mutuals.com, in connection with market timing. One of the executives, Eric McDonald, was also the co-manager of the Vice Fund. All of those charges are still pending, including civil charges against Mutuals.com and two broker-dealers affiliated with it, Connely Dowd Management and MTT Fundcorp.
 A special monitor appointed by a federal court remains in place for Mutuals.com and all its affiliates, including the Vice Fund, to ensure compliance with securities laws. 
 When Mr. McDonald stepped down from the Vice Fund, he left Dan S. Ahrens as its sole manager. Then, in August 2005, Mr. Ahrens left the fund because of disagreements stemming from the charges against the other executives, he said. In March, he started the Gaming and Casino fund, which has a more narrow focus, concentrating on gambling, casino and lottery companies -- politically incorrect territory it shares with the Vice Fund.
 The Vice Fund, now managed by Charles L. Norton, 32, and Michael J. Henry, 26, has stuck to its knitting. Both funds depend on the insight that stocks that exploit the dark side of human nature are a natural for Wall Street, particularly during economic downturns. This philosophy is articulated in Mr. Ahrens's book, ''Investing in Vice,'' (St. Martin's Press, 2004). 
 ''Certain habits, even during bad economic times, don't change,'' Mr. Ahrens wrote. ''No matter what the stock market is doing, people still indulge in what are known as vices: smoking, drinking and gambling.'' Mr. Ahrens added war to the list, calling these sectors good long-term bets. 
 Lately, the approach has again been paying off. Gambling and hotel casino stocks returned 25.3 percent this year through Thursday and 28.9 percent, annualized, in the last five years , according to Morningstar. The S.& P. 1500 Casino and Gaming Index, which tracks 10 stocks from the 1500 index, was up 10.1 percent through Thursday and 21.4 percent, annualized, over the last five years.
 Tobacco stocks posted annualized five-year gains of 20 percent, while those for alcoholic beverages gained 12 percent a year and the aerospace and defense sector, including military contractors, climbed 11.8 percent, according to Morningstar.
 The Vice Fund returned 9.2 percent this year through Thursday, compared with 3.1 percent for the S.& P. 500. Over the last three years, the fund's return has been 20.6 percent, annualized, outpacing the 10.9 percent of the S.& P. 500. The fund has no load, or sales charge, and has an expense ratio of 1.75 percent. Its allocations as of May 31 included roughly 27 percent to casinos, gambling and lotteries; 24 percent to aerospace and defense; 24 percent to alcohol; and 21 percent to tobacco. 
 From inception in March, the Gaming and Casino fund gained 0.8 percent through Thursday.
 Funds that call themselves socially responsible take a very different approach, of course. ''We have a zero tolerance for weapons, alcohol, tobacco, gambling,'' said Christopher H. Brown, portfolio manager of the Pax World Balanced fund, which has more than $2 billion under management, roughly 40 times as much as the Vice Fund. Pax World Balanced returned 2.8 percent this year through Thursday; 10.2 percent, annualized, over the last three years; and 5.1 percent over the last five. 
 The Vice Fund has not experienced a ''full business cycle,'' Mr. Brown said, so ''it remains to be seen how they do in the long run.'' 
 The Vice Fund's aerospace and military portfolio includes some companies that have had financial windfalls because of the war in Iraq, said David Strauss, an equity analyst at UBS Investment Research. General Dynamics, which manufactures armored vehicles, is a case in point, he said. ''Historically, the defense company stocks have performed fairly well in a period of weak economic growth,'' he said.
 Of course, scores of mutual funds have big dollops of certain holdings of the Vice Fund in their own portfolios. ''I think what they've done is taken a good marketing spin to the consumer discretionary sector,'' said Philip Edwards, S.& P.'s managing director of fund research.
 Mr. Norton, one of the current co-managers of the Vice Fund, says he favors quantitative analysis in evaluating companies for its portfolio. He is married and has two children, and says he may be at a bit of a disadvantage when it comes to hands-on research for the fund.
 ''I drink socially, but not regularly,'' he said. ''I don't smoke. I only gamble when I go to Vegas.'' But he said he had a more rollicking lifestyle as a student at Tulane University in New Orleans. ''I do have some experience in the sector,'' he said.
 Jeff Tjornehoj, an analyst for Lipper, credits the Vice Fund for not focusing ''entirely on household names, which tend to be large companies.'' Some of its more off-the-radar investments include the Central European Distribution Corporation, a Polish importer of alcoholic beverages; CryptoLogic, which supplies Internet gambling software; and Viisage Technology, which provides facial recognition security technology.
 The Gaming and Casino fund, which has an expense ratio of 1.7 percent and no load, according to its prospectus, does not have much of a track record yet, but Mr. Ahrens says its portfolio includes a variety of casino, gambling and lottery stocks, including Las Vegas Sands, Penn National Gaming, Scientific Games and Shuffle Master.
 At the Vice Fund, the run of frequent management changes isn't over yet, Mr. Norton said. The fund's current adviser, Mutuals Advisors, plans to outsource management of the fund to GNI Capital, an investment adviser based in Greenville, S.C., he said. A second fund, Generation Wave Growth, of which he and Mr. Henry are co-managers, will also shift to GNI Capital, he said. Mr. Norton said he planned to remain a co-manager of both funds. Allen R. Gillespie, a principal at GNI, will replace Mr. Henry at both of them, he said. 
 THE civil and criminal charges against the former executives of Mutuals.com were filed by the S.E.C. and the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. In addition to Mr. McDonald, Richard A. Sapio and Michele Leftwich were charged. 
 In December 2003, the S.E.C. filed a civil complaint accusing them of market timing and defrauding investors. In March 2004, the United States attorney charged the three with conspiracy to commit securities fraud. Later, in August, those charges were expanded to include wire and mail fraud.
 None of the charges involve the Vice Fund directly. According to the Vice Fund's prospectus, Mr. Sapio controls Mutual Capital Alliance, the parent company of Mutuals Advisors. 
 ''We are negotiating with both the Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission,'' said William M. Ravkind, Mr. Sapio's lawyer. ''The judge has been allowing us time to see if we can have some agreement.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Gambling and casino stocks have risen steeply this year, in another sign that some that some pastimes never go out of style. (Photo by Brian Branch-Price/Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Why U.S. Companies Shouldn't Whine About Taxes

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
TO hear some people talk, the United States is the scourge of the Fortune 500. Despite all the tax cuts that President Bush and Congress have passed in the last five years, business groups and their supporters in Washington complain that the United States imposes higher tax rates on corporate profits than almost any other industrialized country.
 ''Foreign-based competitor companies operate under tax rules that are often more favorable than our own,'' warned R. Glenn Hubbard, a former economic adviser to President Bush and now dean of the Columbia Business School, at a House hearing two weeks ago. ''Current law can result in circumstances that harm the competitiveness of U.S. companies.'' 
Around Washington, the rumblings are growing for ''reform'' of corporate taxes to improve the global competitiveness of American companies. 
 Henry M. Paulson Jr., the incoming Treasury secretary, declared at his confirmation hearing that he wanted to increase ''competitiveness'' in the tax code.
 Can it be true that the United States, where bare-knuckled capitalism is a romantic ideal and being nouveau riche is a badge of honor, is harder on big corporations than ''old Europe'' welfare states like Germany, France and Sweden?
 Don't believe it. There are plenty of problems with the corporate tax code -- rococo complexity, perverse incentives, antique ideas -- but overly high taxes is not one of them. 
 By most measures, the corporate tax burden is lower in the United States than it is in the European Union or in Japan or most other industrialized countries. 
 The political danger, at least from a fiscal standpoint, is that arguments for corporate tax reform will be hijacked to justify another round of corporate tax cuts. That was what happened with the corporate tax overhaul of 2004, which became a grab bag of tax breaks to almost every corner of business, at a net cost of $60 billion over 10 years.
 Those who see the American corporate tax as oppressive point to a striking fact: the standard corporate tax rate of 35 percent is now higher than that of most other industrialized countries. The average top rate is 25.8 percent in the European Union, where most nations have cut rates to attract investment.
 But official tax rates are not the same as actual tax burdens. What American companies lose in high tax rates they more than make up in higher tax breaks. 
 One indicator of the true tax burden is corporate tax revenue as a share of gross domestic product. According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a research organization based in Paris and financed by governments of industrialized nations, corporate taxes in 2003 were 2.1 percent of G.D.P. in the United States, 3.2 percent in the European Union and 4.3 percent in industrialized countries in Asia. 
 Though comparisons of true tax rates are treacherous, the evidence suggests that the United States more than makes up for high statutory rates with generous tax breaks. Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, has calculated that the average corporation paid taxes of about 18 percent in 2004.
 The European Commission, using a more theoretical approach, calculated that the average effective tax rate in 15 Western European nations has hovered between 20 and 22 percent since 1998. When the 10 new Central European members of the European Union are included, the average corporate tax bite was 17.7 percent.
 ''There is good reason to believe that the corporate tax burden in the United States could be less than the rest of the world because the rest of the world has been broadening their tax bases while we have been cutting ours,'' said Martin A. Sullivan, an analyst at the journal Tax Notes. 
 To be sure, many experts contend that the American tax code does impose some competitive disadvantages. One big complaint is that the United States is one of the very few countries that taxes corporate profits worldwide. Almost all other nations use ''territorial'' systems, taxing only profits inside their borders.
 The difference is significant. Thyssen-Krupp, the German steel conglomerate, owes no German taxes on profits from its operations in Brazil, China or Poland. And European value-added tax on domestic sales does not apply to exports to the United States. United States Steel, by contrast, potentially owes American taxes on profits from its subsidiary in Slovakia and must also charge value-added taxes on exports sold in Germany.
 In practice, the disadvantage is smaller than it appears. For one thing, American companies receive tax credits for taxes paid in other countries. More important, American companies have proved extremely adept at shifting profits into low-tax countries like Ireland and then deferring the American taxes on those profits by keeping them outside the United States. 
 Under current federal law, companies can postpone taxes on foreign profits until those profits return to the United States. By some estimates, American multinationals had accumulated more than $400 billion in profits outside the country. 
 Last year, Congress rewarded that behavior. First, it widened companies' ability to claim tax credits against their foreign taxes, at a cost to the Treasury of almost $40 billion over 10 years. Second, it gave companies a one-time chance to repatriate their vast hoard of overseas profits at a tax rate of only 5.25 percent -- a bonanza for many pharmaceutical and electronics businesses.
 ''The current U.S. rules, while complex, represent the best of all worlds for multinational taxpayers,'' declared Stephen E. Shay, a former international tax counsel to the Treasury Department, at a hearing last month of a House Ways and Means subcommittee. 
 MANY analysts agree that today's rules are a mess: they do not raise much revenue from foreign profits, they encourage companies to invest outside the United States, they encourage profit-shifting schemes and they probably put some American companies at a competitive disadvantage. 
 The challenge is to change the system without cutting taxes yet again. Michael J. Graetz, a professor at Yale Law School and a proponent of radical tax overhaul, told lawmakers last month that the top corporate tax rate ought to be cut from 35 percent to as little as 15 percent.
 But Mr. Graetz said Congress would have to make up for the lost revenue. ''It is not possible to achieve this kind of corporate rate reduction without a major restructuring of our domestic tax system,'' he said. 
 President Bush called for exactly such a revenue-neutral restructuring during his re-election campaign. But any overhaul would provoke intense battles between potential winners and losers. With Republicans terrified about losing control of Congress in the midterm elections this year, Mr. Bush has postponed making any proposals until at least next year.

HEADLINE: Flesh Trade

BYLINE: By STEPHEN J. DUBNER and STEVEN D. LEVITT. 
Stephen J. Dubner and Steven D. Levitt are the authors of ''Freakonomics: A Rogue Economist Explores the Hidden Side of Everything.'' More information on the research behind this column is at www.freakonomics.com.

 BODY:
Weighing the Repugnance Factor
 How's this for a repugnant situation? Take someone you love, perhaps your spouse or your sibling, and find a stranger who will accept a really big bet that your loved one will die prematurely -- and if indeed that happens, you pocket a few million dollars.
This, of course, is how life insurance works. And most Americans don't find this idea repugnant at all. They used to, however. Until the mid-19th century, life insurance was considered ''a profanation,'' as the sociologist Viviana Zelizer has written, ''which transformed the sacred event of death into a vulgar commodity.'' 
 Alvin Roth, a Harvard economist who studies the design of markets, has done a lot of thinking about repugnance. On some issues, he notes, repugnance will recede, as with life insurance -- or, even more momentously, the practice of charging interest on loans. In other cases, the reverse happens: a once-accepted behavior like slaveholding comes to be seen as repugnant. 
 One case of repugnance is far from settled: the dispute over how human organs for transplantation should be allocated -- and, perhaps, even sold. If you happen to have a failing heart or liver or kidneys, you will almost certainly die without a transplant, but if you aren't lucky enough to get an organ through an official registry, you can't legally purchase one at any price. So instead of a free market in organs, we have a volunteer market. Some people agree to give up their usable organs once they die. In the case of a living donor, someone sacrifices a kidney or a portion of a liver to a recipient, most likely a family member. 
 In the space of just a few decades, transplant surgery has become safe and reliable (to say nothing of miraculous). But success breeds demand: as more patients get new organs, more patients want them. In 2005, more than 16,000 kidney transplants were performed in the U.S., an increase of 45 percent over 10 years. But during that time, the number of people on a kidney waiting list rose by 119 percent. More than 3,500 people now die each year waiting for a kidney transplant. 
 To an economist, this is a basic supply-and-demand gap with tragic consequences. So what can be done to increase the supply of organs? 
 A big problem is that would-be suppliers are not given very strong incentives to step forward. In much of Europe, the choice is made for them: instead of ''opting in'' to donate, the default assumption is that your usable organs will be harvested upon your death unless your family ''opts out.'' But Europe, too, still has a sizable organ shortage, in part because traffic fatalities -- which tend to produce desirable organs for harvest -- are on a downward trend in Western countries. 
 If it's hard to get people to give up their organs upon death, consider how much harder it is to persuade a living person to donate a kidney. (From a medical perspective, a kidney from a living donor is far more valuable than a cadaver kidney.) Even though most people can live safely on one kidney, there is still a price to be paid in discomfort, risk, fear and lost wages. But the United States, like pretty much every other country in the world, forbids a donor to collect on that price, or any other.
 It is hard to find an economist who agrees with this policy. Gary Becker and Julio Jorge Elias argued in a recent paper that ''monetary incentives would increase the supply of organs for transplant sufficiently to eliminate the very large queues in organ markets, and the suffering and deaths of many of those waiting, without increasing the total cost of transplant surgery by more than 12 percent.'' 
 Some noneconomists may well find this reasoning repugnant. There are many reasons, after all, for banning the sale of organs. Some people consider it immoral to commodify body parts (although it is now commonplace to not only sell sperm and eggs but also to rent a womb). Others fear that most organ sellers would be poor while most buyers would be rich; or that someone might be pressured into selling a kidney without fully understanding the risks. 
 But why, Becker and Elias ask, should poor people ''be deprived of revenue that could be highly useful to them''? Even more compelling is the fact that a poor person is just as likely as a wealthy person (if not more so) to need a new kidney -- and, with no legal market for organs, is just as likely to die while waiting on a list.
 Alvin Roth, even though he is an economist, is smart enough to realize that repugnance will keep Americans from embracing a true market for organs anytime soon. So, along with several other scholars and medical personnel, he has helped design a clever alternative, the New England Program for Kidney Exchange. Imagine that you have a wife who is dying of renal failure, and that you would give her one of your kidneys, but you are not a biological match. Now imagine that another couple is in the same bind. The kidney exchange locates and matches the couples: you donate your kidney to the stranger's wife, while the stranger gives his kidney to your wife; the operations are performed simultaneously to make sure no one backs out. Although this system has yielded only a couple dozen transplants so far, it illustrates an economist's understanding of incentives: if you can't get someone to give an organ out of altruism, and you can't pay him either, what do you do? Find two parties who are desperate to align their incentives. 
 Otherwise, who in his right mind would step forward to donate a kidney to a stranger? In fact, we recently spoke to one such potential donor who asked to remain anonymous. Donor is married, with four children and a precarious financial situation. Because Donor had a sibling who nearly needed an organ transplant, the idea got into Donor's head to perhaps sell a kidney to a stranger. Through a donor Web site, Donor met a potential recipient, whom we'll call Recipient. It wasn't until the process was well under way that Donor learned it was illegal to be paid. In the end, however, Donor's moral mission overrode the financial need, and Donor decided to go ahead with the transplant.
 Donor has undergone extensive testing at the hospital where Recipient will have the transplant. Both Donor and Recipient have had to lie repeatedly to the doctors, pretending they are old friends. ''If they find out you met on the Internet,'' Donor explains, ''they assume it's for money, and they'll call off the operation.''
 If all goes well, the transplant may happen soon. Consider the parties who stand to profit from this transaction: Recipient, certainly, as well as the transplant surgeons, the nurses, the hospital, the drug companies. Everyone will be paid in some form -- except for Donor, who not only isn't being paid but, in return for carrying out a deeply altruistic act, also has to pay the additional price of lying about it.
 Surely there are some people, and not just economists, who would find this situation -- well, repugnant.

LENGTH: 429 words

BYLINE: By ROGER COLLIS

 BODY:

My husband and I would like to go to Thailand, but he is reluctant because, at 6 feet 4 inches, measuring 27 inches from back to knee, he just cannot move his legs in an economy seat with a 31-inch pitch, or less. We cannot afford to fly business class. Can one secure seats, such as exit rows, that might enable him to survive a long flight? 
 -- Johanna Read, Ottawa
 Many readers share the same conundrum. Harold Levine in Paris asks, ''Is there something more comfortable than economy but less than business class'' for a flight to Denver; Keith Spicer, also in Paris, writes, ''As a 71-year-old frequent trans-Atlantic traveler with long legs, I am now limiting my travel; the gap between affordable 'sardine' class and high-cost business class is ridiculous. Why don't airlines recognize there is a market between economy and business? I would gladly pay up to $300 extra each way for a basic business class with more space, a better meal and a bit more service.''
 As it turns out, some airlines are indeed offering more space to travelers unwilling or unable to pay business-class fares. Taiwan-based Eva Air, with its Evergreen Deluxe Class (called Elite Class on its 777's), was the first carrier to provide passengers paying the full economy fare with more legroom in a separate cabin, in 1991. It was followed by Virgin Atlantic with its Premium Economy class, British Airways' World Traveller Plus and United Airlines with Economy Plus, all of which typically offer up to seven inches more legroom than regular cattle class for around one-third the price of a business-class seat. United Airlines does not have a specific fare for Economy Plus but reserves the front section of the economy cabin with more legroom for ''elite-level'' frequent fliers (Mileage Plus members with Premier status or above) and full-fare economy passengers. 
 British Airways' round-trip fares between Kennedy Airport and London, for example, range from $482 to $1,665 in World Traveller (economy) and $669 to $2,180 in World Traveller Plus, to a whopping $3,215 to $9,198 (business class). 
 And consider MAXjet, a trans-Atlantic business-class-only start-up airline that operates a fleet of Boeing 767's with 102 seats that recline to an almost horizontal position and offer a full 60 inches of legroom. Round-trip fares between New York and London and Washington and London range from $1,398 to $4,188; promotional fares can be as low as $1,066.
 You can always check for the best seats (and those to avoid) in any class at www.airlinequality.com or www.seatguru.com. ROGER COLLIS

HEADLINE: The Growing Problem of Fraud 

BYLINE: By BOB TEDESCHI

 BODY:
WITH interest rates at historic lows in recent years, consumers have raced to get mortgages. So have criminals.
 Industry executives and law-enforcement officials say mortgage fraud continues to climb, with lenders incurring more than $1 billion in fraud losses in the last fiscal year, twice the amount of the previous year. And while no organization has yet tracked how much consumers have lost to fraud, anecdotal evidence suggests that those levels, too, are rising sharply.
''The problem is definitely growing,'' said Tim Doyle, the senior director of government affairs at the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington. ''The F.B.I. has prioritized this, state attorneys general are looking at this, and more state laws are being passed about it.'' 
 About 80 percent of mortgage fraud involves professional thieves who are bilking lenders, the F.B.I. estimates, while in the remaining cases consumers are involved in one way or another. 
 This second category is known in law enforcement as ''fraud for property.'' Typically, mortgage applicants falsify financial documents so they can qualify for an out-of-reach mortgage, or their lender or broker falsifies the documents on their behalf, looking for profit or a quick commission. Consumers frequently default on such loans, losing their homes and ruining their credit.
 Fraud against a lender is known as ''fraud for profit.'' In such cases a criminal group works with an unscrupulous appraiser, typically finding a house that has sat on the market for a while at a certain price. They offer the homeowner that price, with a stipulation: the homeowner must allow the criminals' appraiser to value the home at, say, 30 percent higher. 
 A criminal in the ring takes out a loan for the higher amount using stolen financial and personal information. When the criminals get the money, they pay the former homeowner the original asking price, then split the remainder among themselves.
 Harry Dinham, the president of National Association of Mortgage Brokers in McLean, Va., said that although the authorities are trying to combat the problem, it is so widespread they have not yet caught up. ''Criminals have figured out this is a way to make extra money and not get caught on a regular basis,'' he said.
 Ira Rheingold, the executive director of the National Association of Consumer Advocates, a nonprofit legal group in Washington, said prospective homeowners should be wary of unwittingly involving themselves in fraud.
 According to Mr. Rheingold, most consumers who engage in mortgage fraud are subprime borrowers. A predatory lender will push such cash-poor borrowers into loans they cannot afford by overstating their income and assets on the loan application. ''Some applications created by brokers are the greatest pieces of fiction I ever read,'' he said.
 These borrowers are either not sophisticated enough to catch falsifications on the loan's closing documents or simply don't want to lose the chance to live in a particular house.
 To avoid such situations, Mr. Rheingold said, borrowers should know their credit scores and shop around to get a sense of what loan terms they can reasonably expect. Applicants should also demand closing documents early in the process, so they can catch inaccuracies or falsifications before they pack up for the move.
 And although consumers cannot do much to thwart ''fraud for profit,'' they should be aware that such crimes ultimately cost them money, Mr. Dinham said. ''Companies aren't going to continue to lose money on this without charging more,'' he said. ''Anytime you have a problem this broad, consumers end up paying a premium at some point.''

HEADLINE: Betting on Demand for a Castle

BYLINE: By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

DATELINE: SADDLE RIVER 

 BODY:
THERE is a castle being built on speculation here beside the Saddle River: an 18,000-square-foot manse with a turret, two libraries, four laundry rooms, a six-car garage, nine full baths and a 14-seat home theater. The price tag says $12.9 million.
 If they build it, will a buyer come? 
''We're pretty confident -- even in this slower market,'' said Michael Cantor, the head of Pinnacle Homes' custom homes division, which began construction of the castle 11 months ago. ''We could build more $5 million houses here, I guess. I think that's a more risky undertaking in the current environment, frankly, than building this house.''
 Various market reports showed a drastic slowing of the high-end market in New Jersey this spring. Even in highly affluent Bergen County, home of Saddle River, the average time it takes to sell any house priced above $1 million is now 12 months, according to the Otteau Appraisal Group's analyses, which are widely read by real estate professionals.
 Mr. Cantor agreed that the high-end sector is tightening. But in his view, the ''high high-end'' market for a unique house that can set a multimillionaire's heart aflutter in an instant does not wane with interest rate fluctuations or the size of a year-end bonus.
 Even in inflationary times like these, Mr. Cantor noted, ''There are still lots of very rich people around.''
 The 26-room castle, set on an exquisite 4.2-acre property that stretches 850 feet back to the riverbank from East Saddle River Road, was designed with a particular sort of very rich person in mind, he said -- most likely someone in the entertainment field with ties to both coasts. 
 The hip hop mogul Russell Simmons and his brother, the rapper Reverend Run, both live over the line in Upper Saddle River not far from where the castle is rising, as do a number of music and film industry executives. The mystery writer Mary Higgins Clark resides in town. Ashley Olsen, one of the acting twins, has a house here.
 The location provides easy access to the fast lane from a cozy berth of privacy, Mr. Cantor suggested. More than 30 years ago, Richard Nixon found elegant seclusion in Saddle River after leaving the presidency in disgrace.
 On the other hand, this particular abode will most likely appeal to a buyer who relishes holding extravagant parties and inviting revelers to stay over for a few days -- or maybe a few weeks, or months.
 ''Midtown Manhattan is 30 minutes away,'' Mr. Cantor said, ''but here you can live like Great Gatsby. This house is all about entertaining.''
 Designed by the Westwood architect Robert Zampolin, New Jersey's architect to the stars, the house sits behind stone privacy walls and wrought-iron gates opening to a long driveway that terminates in a ''motor court'' accommodating up to 14 vehicles.
 The first floor features an enormous domed foyer opening onto a huge library; a grand dining room with a double-sided fireplace; a breakfast area overlooking the pool and grounds; a kitchen with two islands and a coffee bar (cappuccino available via spigot); an adjoining family room; a household operations room with the computerized controls to the security, electric and heating/cooling systems (also operable by touch screens placed around the house); a pantry; a desk area; a room set aside for wrapping gifts; an elevator vestibule; staff quarters; and a separate guest suite.
 Upstairs, there are numerous bedroom suites and a children's wing with a ''learning center'' and crafts room. The 2,300-square-foot master suite is roughly the same size as the 1950's ranch house that is still standing on the property and is serving as a construction office for Pinnacle Custom until the new house is completed.
 Off the master bedroom, there is a large elevated terrace that shelters another large terrace below, which is part of the pool area.
 The lower level, partly below ground, is the area of the house that is most likely to capture the heart of the person who loves to entertain. It has both a wine cellar and a wine-tasting room, set up like a bistro and featuring a lovely view of the backyard. A fitness center has windows looking onto an indoor basketball court and an adjacent beverage center. 
 This level also has a billiards room and a lounge area with French doors opening to the stone terrace around the pool and the cabana, which itself has a lounge area as well as a full kitchen, full bath, changing room with lockers, and laundry room.
 The history of houses along East Saddle River Road tends to reflect the squat little ranch that will be demolished sometime this fall when work on the driveway and castle motor court begins.
 But the castle is more in line with what is going on now -- there is a gargantuan Mediterranean abode being custom-built two doors away -- and may well point to the future in the neighborhood, Mr. Cantor said.
 His company is always searching the area for opportunities to maximize the value of a special piece of property, he said, just as it is constantly scouting in other tony spots like nearby Alpine and Greenwich, Conn., for a castle-capacity property, he said.
 ''In a place like Greenwich, they do lots of teardowns in order to build new mansion-type homes,'' he said. ''But in this part of New Jersey, there are still some properties like this, in semirural spots and horse farm towns, that have been virtually untouched all this time.''
 There is an ancient grove of trees circling a pond edged with stones that is back by the river on the expansive East Saddle River Road site, he noted. ''It's like having a piece of Central Park in your backyard,'' he said, ''but hardly anyone has ever even seen it. It has just been waiting to be discovered.''

HEADLINE: Deregulating a Stabilized Apartment 

 BODY:

Q. I have heard that once the monthly rent in a stabilized apartment surpasses $2,000, it can be deregulated if the tenants' income is high enough. Can you describe the terms under which this can occur? Mitch Horowitz, Manhattan

A. Mary Ann Hallenborg, a Manhattan lawyer and the author of ''New York Tenants' Rights'' (Nolo, 2002), said that under the ''luxury decontrol'' provision of the rent laws, once a tenant's rent is $2,000 a month or more, the landlord may be entitled to remove the apartment from regulation. 
 For an apartment to be deregulated, total annual income for all tenants in the household must be $175,000 or more for each of the previous two years. '' 'Annual income' means your federal adjusted gross income as reported on your New York State income tax return,'' Ms. Hallenborg said. ''And 'total annual income' means the sum of annual incomes for all permanent occupants of the apartment.''
To deregulate an apartment, the landlord must send the tenant an Income Certification Form by May 1, she said. The tenant must return the form within 30 days, indicating if the total annual household income is $175,000 or not. 
 If the total annual household income is $175,000 or more, the landlord must file a petition for deregulation with the Division of Housing and Community Renewal by June 30. The agency will then issue a deregulation order within 30 days. 
 If the tenant does not return the certification form on time, the landlord can file the petition, and the agency will ask state tax officials to review the tenants' tax returns to determine if the income threshold has been exceeded. 

Does the Managing Agent Have Conflicting Interests?

Q. I live in a co-op, and the managing agent is on the board of directors as the sponsor's designee. Is this a conflict of interest? Valerie Duval, Hartsdale, N.Y.

A. ''The agent's interests as a building manager could easily come into conflict with the agent's fiduciary duties as a board member,'' said Kenneth Jacobs, a co-op lawyer with offices in Yonkers and Manhattan.
 ''And the potential for conflicts would be even greater if the agent was appointed to the board as the sponsor's designee,'' he said, ''because the agent would then have to balance his own interests with the interests of the sponsor and the interests of the co-op.'' 
 Co-op boards rely on their managing agents for advice on running the building, Mr. Jacobs said, and since the sponsor, who is usually a nonresident, may have different opinions from those of residents on many issues, his designee may not be able to render objective advice.
 In this case, the co-op board should keep a close eye on the managing agent, he said, and if necessary, it should replace him.

HEADLINE: Which Fund Does An Adviser Love More?

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT. 
Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of MarketWatch. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IS a mutual fund a better bet if it is managed by a firm that also runs a hedge fund? You might think so, since the arrangement could give investors access to hedge-fund-quality acumen at the lower cost of a mutual fund. 
 It may work out that way for some hedge fund-mutual fund combinations. But a new study has concluded that mutual funds are often victimized in such pairings, because firms that manage both kinds generally have financial incentives that favor hedge funds over mutual funds. 
The study recently began circulating in academic circles as a working paper and was presented late last month at the Western Finance Association. Its authors are Scott Gibson, associate professor of finance at the Mason Business School of the College of William and Mary; Gjergji Cici, who has accepted an appointment as an assistant professor of finance there this fall; and Rabih Moussawi, associate director of research data services at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. A copy is at papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract-id=905600. The researchers say it offers empirical support for concerns expressed in a 2003 staff report of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
 Until the mid-1990's, when the hedge fund industry began to grow quickly, it was relatively rare for mutual funds and hedge funds to be managed by the same investment advisory firm. In 2004, though, the latest year for which data were available, 325 actively managed equity mutual funds were run by firms that also ran hedge funds. Collectively, those 325 managed more than $448 billion. Professor Gibson says he wouldn't be surprised if such side-by-side management relationships were even more common today.
 While performance incentives are rare among mutual funds, they are the norm among hedge funds. The manager of a hedge fund typically keeps a large percentage of his fund's profits -- as much as 20 percent, and sometimes even more. 
 Another difference is that hedge funds are lightly regulated, and they are free of many of the rules that keep mutual funds from pursuing esoteric and complex strategies like selling short or investing in derivatives. Some of these strategies enable a hedge fund to make money even in a falling market. Because of these differences, talented mutual fund managers have a powerful incentive to become hedge fund managers, according to Joseph Sack, executive vice president of the Bond Market Association, a trade association whose members include senior executives of most major asset management firms. To help prevent a brain drain away from mutual funds, Mr. Sack and many other asset managers argue, mutual fund companies shouldn't be prevented from allowing their managers to run hedge funds as well.
 Such side-by-side management arrangements, however, are fraught with significant conflicts of interest, according to the 2003 report prepared by the S.E.C.'s division of investment management. A firm that manages both kinds of funds generally earns more if its hedge fund performs well than if its mutual fund does. This creates powerful incentives to favor the hedge fund by ''allocating investment opportunities to the hedge fund,'' the 2003 report said. 
 The S.E.C.'s staff hasn't seen the new academic study and has no comment on it, said John D. Heine, an S.E.C. spokesman.
 Until the completion of the new study, the debate over side-by-side management arrangements remained theoretical. Professor Gibson says he is aware of no other study that resolves it empirically. 
 He and his co-authors focused on 457 actively managed equity mutual funds that, at least some of the time from 1994 to 2004, were run by firms that also managed hedge funds. For each of these funds, the professors selected a group of comparable funds that were identical in major respects except that the managers of these corresponding funds were not affiliated with a hedge fund.
 The authors found strong support for the S.E.C.'s concern about the effects of conflicts of interest. On average, the authors found, the 457 mutual funds underperformed the comparable funds by 1.2 percent a year. The researchers estimated that the lower performance in effect represented a wealth transfer of $5.6 billion in 2004 from the advisory firms' mutual funds to their hedge funds. 
 The researchers say that their results reflect an average across the 457 funds, and that some individual mutual funds affiliated with hedge funds did better than the comparable mutual funds. The researchers did not gain access to trading records and therefore had no specific knowledge about how any particular firm might have favored its hedge fund over its mutual fund.
 Nevertheless, the researchers argue that there is no shortage of ways in which a firm could show such favoritism. Some are blatant, like having the hedge fund trade in advance of the mutual fund -- a practice known as front-running -- which in some instances would probably be illegal. Others are subtler -- if a firm, for example, allocates to its hedge fund any portions of hot initial public offerings that the firm receives.
 THIS last practice was the only method of playing favorites that the researchers could nail down with any certainty. They found that mutual funds run by firms that also managed hedge funds received significantly fewer shares of I.P.O.'s than did the comparable mutual funds. Basing their conclusion on statistical analysis, the researchers said they were confident that the difference couldn't be attributed merely to chance.
 The study clearly suggests that investors should avoid mutual funds managed by firms that also run hedge funds. But there is a broader message as well: conflicts of interest are not just theoretical; they can influence managers' behavior. 
 Professor Gibson recommends careful study of the incentives under which an advisory firm operates. If those incentives aren't aligned with your own, he says, stay away.

HEADLINE: In a U-Turn Quarter, a Retreat From Risk

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM

 BODY:
MUTUAL fund investors who hitched their wagons to the speculative frenzy that propelled the markets earlier this year learned a valuable but costly lesson in the second quarter.
 Investment bandwagons have a nasty habit of reversing course without warning. And ''this was one of those U-turn type quarters,'' said Ernest M. Ankrim, chief investment strategist at the Russell Investment Group in Tacoma, Wash.
As central banks around the world tightened monetary conditions, investors appeared to lose all appetite for taking risks. Partly as a result, the average general domestic stock mutual fund tumbled 2.9 percent in the three months through June. 
 The losses would have been much more severe if not for an 11th-hour rally in stocks on June 29, the day before the quarter ended. That was the day the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates for the 17th consecutive time in the last two years, but intimated that it might soon pause. 
 Among all domestic stock funds, including sector portfolios, the average quarterly loss was also 2.9 percent, according to Morningstar, the fund tracker. That was significantly worse than the 0.1 percent gain of taxable bond funds and marked a reversal from the first quarter, when domestic stock funds gained 6.4 percent.
 Despite the recent sell-off in equities, though, domestic stock funds have managed gains of 10.9 percent over the last 12 months, which is almost exactly in line with historical norms.
 What was not normal was the degree of speculation that stock investors exhibited earlier this year, in the fourth year of an aging bull market. Traditionally, investors bet big on risky assets early in a bull market, and then gradually become more conservative. But in the first quarter, investors were pouring money into speculative stocks, like those in emerging-market funds, which rose 12.3 percent in the first three months of this year. That helped to feed heightened interest in foreign stocks in general.
 Unfortunately, those emerging-market stock funds were slammed harder than domestic holdings during the second-quarter storm that began in May, when the Fed started to sound hawkish on inflation. The average diversified emerging-market stock fund lost 5.1 percent over the last three months, according to Morningstar; stock funds that specialize in Latin America declined 3.2 percent, on average.
 To be sure, over the last five years, emerging-market stock portfolios are still among the best performers, with annualized gains of 20.8 percent. That compares with an average loss of 0.1 percent for large-cap domestic growth funds.
 Nevertheless, the recent rockiness in emerging markets is part of a larger theme, said Jeffrey J. Schappe, chief investment officer at BB&T Asset Management in Raleigh, N.C. ''We're seeing a very significant correction,'' he said, ''in the riskiest asset classes.'' 
 Tom Roseen, senior research analyst at Lipper, the fund tracker, said that among domestic stock funds, ''the area that probably got punished the worst was science and technology.'' The average technology fund lost 9.7 percent of its value in the second quarter, while telecommunications funds, on average, dropped 4.4 percent.
 AMONG general domestic stock funds, those that invest in growth-oriented equities were hit much harder than so-called value funds. The average large-cap growth fund lost 4.7 percent, while the average large-cap value fund fell 0.1 percent.
 Investors in the second quarter also saw a long-anticipated end to small-stock dominance. For the first time in a long while, large blue-chip stock funds outperformed riskier small-company stock portfolios by a meaningful margin. Small-cap growth funds sank 6.7 percent.
 Already, professional money managers have begun shifting their emphasis back toward large-cap stocks.
 According a June survey of money managers by the Russell Investment Group, a vast majority are now bullish on large-cap shares in general. When asked about their view of small-cap growth and small-cap value stocks, meanwhile, more money managers called themselves bearish than said they were bullish. 
 Mr. Roseen of Lipper said he would not be surprised if the same shift in attitude occurred among mutual fund investors. He said those investors, fearful of rising market volatility, ''now have a 'pay me now' mentality,'' which is likely to renew interest in large-cap portfolios. Such funds tend to throw off more dividends than their small-cap counterparts. 
 A shift toward stability and away from speculation has already begun to drive some investors out of the emerging markets. While international stock funds in general continued to attract net inflows of new money in May, investors redeemed a net $916 million out of emerging-market stock funds, according to Lipper. 
 Because of hefty losses in the emerging markets and Japan -- the average Japanese stock fund was down 7.8 percent in the last quarter -- the average international stock fund fell 1.5 percent. Still, that was better than the performance of domestic portfolios.
 Whether investors in the United States continue to bet big overseas may well depend on how the domestic stock market performs for the remainder of the year.
 Some market watchers said the volatility that began in May could mean a rocky summer for equities. Jeffrey A. Hirsch, editor of The Stock Trader's Almanac, said he thought that the equity market was headed for ''an old-fashioned bear market'' sometime later this year. ''We've got a bull that's running out of reasons to be bullish,'' he said.
 Mr. Hirsch added that because this was the second year of a presidential term, the markets were ripe for a real downturn. These midterm years have historically been the worst for stocks. 
 Others are not so pessimistic. Neil J. Hennessy, president and portfolio manager of Hennessy Funds, said that while economic and corporate-profit growth might be slowing somewhat, the underlying health of the economy was still strong.
 ''By historic standards, we still have relatively low interest rates, low unemployment and low inflation,'' he said. 
 Mr. Hennessy said the Dow Jones industrial average, which closed as high as 11,642.65 on May 10 before falling nearly 1,000 points by mid-June, could hit 12,000 by the end of the year. ''We've got 180 days before year's end,'' he said. ''All it would take is 10 days of 100-point moves, and everything could be a wash for the rest of the year.''
 REGARDLESS of the economic outlook, Mr. Schappe of BB&T Asset Management said investors should consider focusing more on higher-quality stocks. Just as blue-chip stocks and stock funds are likely to hold up better in a downturn, they may also provide decent growth if the market regains its footing this year, he said. Wall Street, he said, has largely overlooked the strong earnings and fundamentals of large-cap companies lately. 
 An emphasis on quality also applies to foreign investing, he said. Investors would do well to embrace high-quality large-cap foreign stocks and stock funds in the developed markets, he said, rather than playing the momentum game of the emerging markets or fleeing international equities altogether. 
 Investors enjoyed huge returns with seemingly little risk even in highly volatile investments at the start of the year. But that was when equity prices were going through the roof. If the second quarter proved anything, Mr. Schappe said, it was that ''risk is being put back'' into the risk-return relationship.

HEADLINE: Calories, Economics And the Sweetener Debate

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''Does This Goo Make You Groan?'' (July 2), about the debate over high-fructose corn syrup: 
 It's not that high-fructose corn syrup, in and of itself, is harmful. As you point out, its mixture of fructose and glucose is nearly the same as that in sucrose, table sugar. The importance of the syrup lies in its economics: it is much cheaper to produce than sucrose, and its consumption has soared as the food industry has pushed all of us to consume more of it in processed foods. 
 Total caloric consumption is what matters in obesity, and caloric sweeteners are especially important, whether high-fructose corn syrup, sucrose or the mixture of naturally occurring sugars in ''100 percent fruit juice.'' Government data demonstrate unequivocally that Americans are taking in more calories now than 25 years ago. 

Alan Meyers, M.D.
Boston, July 2

The writer is associate professor of pediatrics at Boston University Medical Center.

To the Editor:
 I am a scientist with 25 years in the food industry, including involvement in research leading to the replacement of sucrose with high-fructose corn syrup in carbonated beverages. 
 Though high-fructose corn syrup is easy to spot on many labels on grocery store shelves, its purposes in foods and beverages are not fully appreciated by most consumers. More than just a sweetener, it keeps food fresh longer by inhibiting microbial growth, enhances fruit and spice flavors, improves surface browning of breads and gives a soft texture to baked goods. 
 Like all nutritive sweeteners, it contains calories. But critics who attack a single ingredient as the sole cause of obesity are wrong and counterproductive. A quixotic search for an easy answer means true solutions to the obesity problem are not being found.

John S. White, Ph.D.
Argenta, Ill., July 3

The writer is president of White Technical Research, which does consulting on nutritive sweeteners for the food industry.

To the Editor:
 Glucose, sucrose, fructose. What does it matter? Isn't weight gain or loss ultimately the equation of ''calories in'' minus ''calories burned''? Every drop of high-fructose corn syrup you ingest adds to your waistline, while benefiting its manufacturers' bottom line.

Elizabeth R. Cardman
Urbana, Ill., July 3

To the Editor:
 What isn't mentioned in debates over high-fructose corn syrup is the taste. As far as I'm concerned, this is the real objection to putting the syrup into so many products. 
 High-fructose corn syrup has a quality, absent from cane sugar, that I would call cloying, an undertone that most people come to take for granted after a few decades of eating it in everything they buy.

Anne Mendelson
North Bergen, N.J., July 3

HEADLINE: Are Large Caps Back in Style?

BYLINE: By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN

 BODY:
AMID rising interest rates and market volatility, many investment strategists say it is time to refocus on those core investments: large-capitalization domestic stock funds. 
 ''We feel very strongly that the tide has gone out with respect to more-risky asset classes,'' said Nick Bohnsack, investment strategist at the ISI Group in New York. ''Investors should look toward higher-quality asset classes, and in our view the most attractive is U.S. large caps.''
 Despite their usually prominent position in investor portfolios, large-capitalization domestic stocks and stock funds, which include Standard & Poor's 500-stock index funds, have been out of favor with investors in recent years, and no wonder. Domestic small-cap stock funds and emerging-market funds outperformed domestic large caps for the three years through April 2006, posting gains of better than 20 percent a year. The S.& P. 500 returned 14.7 percent, annualized, during that period. 
 Investors actually pulled a net $10.2 billion out of large-cap blend funds in 2005 and early 2006, according to the Financial Research Corporation. That was the first time investors took money out of this group of core stock funds since 1994, when the company began tracking fund categories. Large-cap blend funds meld growth and value characteristics in a single portfolio. 
 ''Market history is highly cyclical: winners become losers and vice versa,'' said Francis M. Kinniry Jr., a principal in the investment counseling and research group at Vanguard. ''Investors would do themselves a huge service by going back to core funds,'' he said.
 At the end of June, there were signs that money was flowing back into large-cap stock funds, with domestic funds reporting net inflows of $20 million for the week ended June 28, according to AMG Data. TheiShares Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks reported net outflows of $2.47 billion, AMG reported.
 The valuation of large-cap domestic stocks has become more attractive. Since December 2001, operating earnings for the stocks in the S.& P. 500 have soared 113 percent, to an estimated $21.22 a share at the end of the second quarter. The S.& P. 500 index, meanwhile, rose a total of 10.6 percent. 
 Because of investor neglect of large caps in the face of rising earnings, the average price-to-earnings ratio of S.& P. 500 stocks has fallen almost in half since 2001. It was 15.7 times estimated 2006 operating earnings at the end of the second quarter, compared with a multiple of 29.55 in 2001. That P/E is 20 percent below the average since 1988, according to Sam Stovall, chief investment strategist at S.& P.
 Jeffrey S. Coons, co-director of research at Manning & Napier Advisors, which manages $12 billion in assets, notes that the Russell 2000 small-cap index now sells at a 20 percent premium to the Russell 1000 large-cap index, based on their price-to-earnings ratios. The last time that happened was in 1983, just before large caps embarked on an extended period of superior performance. 
 ''Right now, we're finding many more good large-cap opportunities,'' said Mr. Coons, whose firm invests in both large- and small-cap stocks. The company manages the Exeter Pro-Blend Maximum Term and Exeter Tax-Managed funds.
 Large-cap earnings are expected to continue to grow at a healthy clip. Earnings of S.& P. 500 companies are likely to rise 12 percent in 2006, according to Standard & Poor's. 
 The economic and market environment, meanwhile, has become increasingly difficult. The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates 17 times in the last two years, and those higher rates will eventually result in slower economic growth. And slower growth and less liquidity in the financial system are expected to exact a higher toll on small companies than on large ones. 
 Large companies generally have more diversified product lines and access to cheaper sources of capital than small companies do. ''A bigger ship can handle a blow better than a rowboat,'' said Christopher Davis, a fund analyst at Morningstar. 
 In the second quarter, large-cap core funds were down 2.13 percent, compared with a 4.4 percent decline in small-cap funds, according to Morningstar.
 No one really knows whether small caps' day in the sun is really over, of course.
 ''We continue to see earnings forecasts for small- and mid-cap stocks that are very good,'' said Philip Edwards, managing director of portfolio services at S.& P. ''I'm not predicting a time when small caps won't do as well as large caps, but all good things must come to an end.'' Earnings for the S.& P. 600 SmallCap index are expected to rise 18 percent this year. But even if small-cap funds continue to perform well, some advisers say, investors should consider taking profits in sectors that have done well and redirect money to areas of the market with better value.
 ''People have overallocated to small-cap and international in the last three years, plus those markets have outperformed,'' said Gregory D. Sullivan, managing director at Sullivan Bruyette Speros & Blayney, a wealth management firm in McLean, Va. ''Now's the time to trim back on the parts of your portfolio that have done so well and reallocate your investments back to the core.'' 
 Mr. Sullivan's preferred method for investing in large-cap stocks is exchange-traded funds that track the S.& P. 500 or the Morgan Stanley Capital International U.S. Prime Market 750 index. Since 2001, Mr. Sullivan has bought $170 million of large-cap core E.T.F.'s for his clients. 
 He likes E.T.F.'s because of their low cost, tax efficiency and ability to trade throughout the day. ''That provides some peace of mind for clients,'' he said. 
 The expense ratio on the SPDR E.T.F., which tracks the S.& P. 500 index, is 0.1 percent, while the expense ratio for the Vanguard Large-Cap E.T.F., which tracks the MSCI 750 index, is 0.07 percent. 
 ''They're just an incredibly efficient way to buy into this basket of stocks,'' Mr. Sullivan said.
 Other options are index mutual funds like Fidelity Spartan 500 Index, with an expense ratio of 0.1 percent, or Vanguard 500 Index, at 0.18 percent. 
 ''These funds are the low-cost leaders,'' Mr. Davis of Morningstar said. ''That's why they're our favorites.'' 
 Actively managed large-cap blend funds are another way to gain exposure to large-cap stocks, said Josh Weiss, a partner and co-chief investment officer at Litman/Gregory Asset Management in Orinda, Calif., an investment adviser and sponsor of the Masters Select group of funds.
 ''We believe we can find great managers,'' he said.
 Among large blend funds, Mr. Weiss recommended Selected American, a fund run by Christopher C. Davis and Kenneth C. Feinberg. Mr. Weiss said this was a ''true core fund'' with a well-diversified portfolio. 
 Mr. Davis and Mr. Feinberg run a portion of the Masters Select Equity fund, as does Bill Miller, manager of Legg Mason Value Trust, another fund that Mr. Weiss likes. 
 AMONG actively managed funds, Mr. Davis of Morningstar recommends Vanguard PrimeCap Core, which opened in December 2004. The team that runs the fund is the same one that manages the Vanguard PrimeCap fund, which is closed to new investors. 
 In the large-cap blend category, Mr. Edwards of S.& P. likes the Pioneer Fund, the Thornburg Value fund and the Victory Diversified Stock fund. All have managers who have compiled strong, consistent track records over an extended period.
 Mr. Davis said investors should not overthink the current state of the market when they rebalance their portfolios.
 ''I wouldn't focus on trying to time this just right,'' he said. ''No one knows when or what is going to turn things around for large-company stocks. But this is the area of the market where you're going to find core holdings for your portfolio. You need core holdings in any environment.''

HEADLINE: Cash May Not Be King, but It's Wielding More Power

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM. 
Paul J. Lim is a financial writer at U.S. News & World Report. E-mail: fund@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AFTER 17 interest rate increases from the Federal Reserve over the last two years, money managers are souring on many investments, including small-company stocks, emerging market equities and real estate.
 But investors have become more bullish on at least one investment of late: cash. In fact, nearly 40 percent of fund managers are holding more cash in their portfolios than they normally do, according to a recent survey by Merrill Lynch.
''I can't recall a time when we've used cash the way we've used it this year,'' said Jeffrey L. Knight, lead manager of the Putnam Asset Allocation funds. Usually, his funds hold close to no cash, in an effort to be fully invested in stocks and bonds. But this year, Mr. Knight has increased his cash positions to around 10 percent. 
 For individual investors, the question is, are there ways to follow the lead of Mr. Knight and other fund managers without upsetting long-term asset allocation plans?
 It's understandable why the pros are so enamored of cash. Thanks to the Federal Reserve, which has gradually lifted its target for its benchmark short-term interest rate to 5.25 percent from 1 percent in 2004, money market mutual funds are now paying out 4.6 percent, on average, three-month Treasury bills are yielding nearly 5 percent and some one-year bank certificates of deposit are paying 5 percent or more.
 ''It's hard to pass up a sure thing earning 5 percent,'' said Ernest M. Ankrim, chief investment strategist at the Russell Investment Group in Tacoma, Wash. The risk-free returns being offered in the money markets are especially attractive in a volatile year when many blue-chip stocks are showing losses.
 But unlike professional fund managers, individuals shouldn't just weigh the short-term prospects of one asset class against another and shift accordingly. Individuals have to consider their long-term goals and should be careful not to let day-to-day market trends lead them astray.
 Still, there are ways for individuals to ''incorporate some flexibility'' into asset allocation plans, to take advantage of today's cash returns, Mr. Knight said. 
 For starters, you can simply be more patient when you deploy new money. 
 After the market sell-off that began in May, many assets are trading 5 percent to 10 percent below their recent highs. Some investors may be tempted to step back into the market and buy on the second-quarter dip.
 But Nick Nanda, asset allocation specialist at GMO, the investment management firm in Boston, said the relatively high yields of cash allow investors to take a wait-and-see approach. ''Why should I be greedy?'' Mr. Nanda said. ''Why not wait until there's more clarity in the markets?''
 The historically high return for cash ''makes waiting more palatable,'' said James B. Stack, editor of InvesTech Market Analyst, a newsletter. And if stocks fall more this summer, cash will become even more valuable to investors than the current 5 percent yields imply. That's because ''cash will buy more stocks later on when they're cheaper,'' Mr. Stack said. 
 ''People tend not to think of it this way,'' he added, ''but the value of cash in your portfolio literally rises whenever other assets fall.'' Investors are often reminded that they should rebalance their portfolios at least once or twice a year. That means taking some profits off the table in winning investments and using the proceeds to add to positions in other asset classes that haven't been performed as well. 
 But there's no rule that says you have to rebalance in one fell swoop. Instead of immediately redeploying money back into the markets when you sell some of your winning stocks, consider dollar-cost averaging that money back into the markets. Dollar-cost averaging means spreading out your purchases over routine intervals, perhaps every month or every quarter, instead of making one lump-sum investment.
 Normally, the downside of such a strategy is that by waiting to put all your money back to work, you'll lose out on some stock market gains, because cash generally underperforms stocks and bonds. The cash drag is one reason that many professional money managers try to be fully invested at all times. 
 But today, cash probably isn't dragging your portfolio. It may be leading it. And ''dollar-cost averaging can be a very effective way to moderate the downside risk of an investment, particularly an investment in a volatile category'' like emerging markets, Mr. Knight said. 
 ''Of course, equity investors aren't the only ones thinking of raising cash. Bond investors are probably asking themselves, ''Why do I need to buy a 10-year Treasury note when I can get a C.D. paying 5 percent?'' said Marilyn Cohen, president of Envision Capital Management, based in Los Angeles.
 Generally, long-term bonds pay investors higher yields than short-term securities because they tie up your money for longer periods of time. But today, this so-called yield curve between short- and long-term securities is pretty flat. 
 Ms. Cohen says fixed-income investors can take advantage of the attractive yields of cash, without upsetting their long-term allocations, by simply investing the interest income thrown off by their long-term bonds into cash instruments rather than re-investing it into new long-term bonds. ''There's real value in six-month and three-month Treasuries,'' she said.
 BUT if you take this approach, ''you have to be nimble,'' she said. Given the uncertainties surrounding the economy, the Fed may have to start cutting interest rates early in 2007. If that happens, your cash accounts are likely to pay less next year than they do today. 
 ''The big challenge for individual investors, once they're in cash, is to know when to get out of cash,'' said Mr. Ankrim of the Russell Investment Group.
 For individuals, it's important to remember that cash, by its nature, is a short-term asset. It's often simply a place to park your money while you decide what to do in the long term. 
 So if you choose to raise cash in the coming weeks, remember that the meter is running. Be on the lookout for better long-term places to stash that cash as opportunities present themselves in stocks and bonds later this year.
